HEADLINE: A Record Buyout Turns Sour for Investors

BYLINE: PETER LATTMAN


HIGHLIGHT: A $45 billion buyout in 2007 of the Texas utility TXU, later renamed Energy Future Holdings, has turned out poorly for its investors because of declining natural gas prices. 

 BODY:
Struck at the peak of the buyout boom five years ago, the $45 billion acquisition of the Texas energy giant TXU - the biggest leveraged buyout in history - has been a painful investment for its private equity owners.
They did not need Warren E. Buffett to remind them how bad things were.
America's most famous investor, in his annual shareholder letter on Saturday, highlighted his $2 billion wrong-way bet on the bonds of the company, which its new owners have renamed Energy Future Holdings. He called the investment "a big mistake" and said it was at risk of losing all of its value.
 "In tennis parlance, this was a major unforced error," Mr. Buffett wrote.
Mr. Buffett's grim view of his Energy Future Holdings position underscores the troubles facing the Texas utility, which is owned by a group of private equity firms led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, TPG Capital and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs.
Last week, Energy Future Holdings reported a 2011 loss of $1.9 billion amid record low natural gas prices. Its retail business has lost about 17 percent of its customers over the last three years to cheaper rivals. Worsening the company's weak financial performance is its prodigious debt load of $35 billion, most of which was added to the balance sheet to finance the buyout.
Energy Future Holdings was the biggest of the so-called megabuyouts - huge deals struck during the market boom of 2005 to 2007. After the financial crisis hit, it seemed that these deals were destined for bankruptcy. Instead, most of them - a group that includes Freescale Semiconductor and Caesars Entertainment - have made it through the downturn, though the investment returns on these deals are expected to be modest. A few, like the hospital chain H.C.A., have earned big profits.
Not so with Energy Future Holdings. For now, the $8.3 billion in equity invested in the deal by the private equity owners has been all but wiped out on paper. K.K.R. is holding its Energy Future Holdings investment at 10 cents on the dollar, or down 90 percent, according to its latest securities filing.
Allan Koenig, a spokesman for Energy Future Holdings, defended the company. He said it was operating extremely well across all of its businesses, had increased its employment by 25 percent under private equity ownership, and was hedged against low natural gas prices this year. The company's weak financial performance won't cause any defaults on its debt obligations, he said, because it has restructured its balance sheet so the first maturities on its bonds do not come due until 2014.
Yet a growing chorus of analysts and bond investors is skeptical of Energy Future Holdings' ability to survive under its current debt-heavy capital structure. The company's bonds are trading at deeply distressed levels that suggest a high likelihood of default. Energy Future Holdings bonds due in 2015 recently traded at 28 cents on the dollar, offering a yield of 60 percent.
"If natural gas prices remain low, there is no way this can work in the long run," said Peter J. Thornton, an analyst at KDP Investment Advisors. 
Energy Future Holdings has avoided deeper problems by tapping the hot market for high-yield debt, or junk bonds. With the Federal Reserve signaling low interest rates into 2014, investors are shunning Treasuries and pushing into riskier bonds that pay higher yields.
This has allowed troubled companies like Energy Future Holdings to raise money in the bond market. In recent weeks, the company raised about $1.1 billion in high-yield bonds in part to repay loans that it owed to one of its subsidiaries.
But Mr. Thornton, the KDP analyst, said that repeatedly tapping the bond market to raise new funds was a Band-Aid solution to a larger problem.
"It seems to us that they're effectively borrowing more now to increase cash and be able to pay interest in the future," he said. "That's not a good long-term strategy."
The TXU takeover, which was announced in February 2007, was not supposed to turn out this way. A storied century-old business originally called Texas Power & Light, TXU was one of the most profitable utilities in the country. It operated in the large and deregulated Texas electricity market, with holdings that included the state's biggest power-generation business and largest electricity retailer. And as the economy boomed, demand for electricity rose.
It was such a promising deal that several of Wall Street's largest banks - Lehman Brothers and Citigroup among them - invested alongside K.K.R., TPG and Goldman.
The new owners recruited several Texas power brokers to join Energy Future Holdings and help the heavily regulated utility with government relations. They named as chairman Donald L. Evans, the former commerce secretary under President George W. Bush. James A. Baker III, a senior official in the Reagan and Bush administrations, was named advisory chairman.
While Mr. Evans and Mr. Baker have assisted the company on political and regulatory issues, they have no control over the price of natural gas, which has fallen since the buyout, putting pressure on the price of wholesale electricity.
Natural gas prices dropped to a 10-year low of $2.32 per million British thermal units last month, from about $13 during the summer of 2008, mainly because of an unusually warm winter. Andrew DeVries, an analyst at CreditSights, estimates that natural gas needs to reach a price of at least $6.15 for Energy Future Holdings to break even after its interest payments and other expenses.
Consensus expectations put long-term natural gas prices between $4.50 and $5, according to the futures market and an average of Wall Street analysts estimates as compiled by Bloomberg.
"The low price of natural gas provides a significant challenge for the company," John F. Young, the chief executive of Energy Future Holdings, acknowledged in the company's earnings call last week.
One reason for the plummeting price of natural gas has been the sharp rise in domestic natural gas exploration, which has created more supply. Extracting natural gas from shale, through a controversial process called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, has created a drilling boom in the United States.
K.K.R. and TPG have benefited from the shale exploration boom in other areas of their private equity portfolios. K.K.R., for example, has had success investing in so-called shale plays. Beginning in 2009, the company placed two bets on natural gas exploration companies. It has since sold those investments, making billions in profit that offset the paper losses in Energy Future Holdings.
Those profits will not help the owners of Energy Future Holdings bonds, who would normally be among the first in line to recouping their investments in a restructuring. But given the company's dim prospects, even bondholders are worried. Mr. Buffett, the company's most prominent bondholder, said in his annual letter that unless gas prices rose substantially, the company's ability to pay interest on its bonds would soon be exhausted.
"Before the leveraged buyout, this was a highly profitable utility," said James Hempstead, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service. "Five years later, the company finds itself in deep financial distress with an untenable capital structure. The game may not be over just yet, but the prospects don't look so good."

HEADLINE: Election 2012: Teaching Ideas and Resources

BYLINE: THE LEARNING NETWORK


HIGHLIGHT: Bookmark this page! We suggested ways to teach about Election 2012 and included links to lesson plans and Times features, and we'll be updating the page regularly as the march to the White House proceeds. 

 BODY:
 Update: Nov. 6, 2012 
 New | Nov. 2012 

        
Ways to Engage: Election Night
        
Student Opinion Question | Who Do You Hope Wins the Election?
 New | Oct, 2012 

        
Teaching the Election in the Final Week: Bellwethers, Unicorns and Attack Ads
        
6 Q's About the News | Voter ID Laws and Election 2012
        
A Reader Idea, "Students Create Video Ads for Historical Presidential Elections,"
        
Lesson | Ideas for Addressing Mormonism in the Classroom
        
 Our Student Opinion Questions: "What Is Your Reaction to the First Presidential Debate?" thesecond presidential debate and the third? 
        
Ideas | Teaching With the Presidential Debates
        
A Student Crossword on Election 2012
        
A matching quiz on Presidential Election History
 New | Sept. 2012 

        
Our Election 2012 Unit
        
A special Student Opinion Contest
        
Our List of Free Election Web Sites

Here are some suggestions for teaching and learning about the 2012 election season, followed by selected New York Times features and Learning Network lesson plans. Bookmark this page: we'll be adding activity ideas and resources as the march to the White House proceeds, and will link from here to all the election resources we publish.Meanwhile, we'd love to hear from you! Please share how you're approaching the election with students in the comment box below.Our Election 2012 UnitWe've designed our Election 2012 Unit to put teenagers front and center of this election. Students become the researchers, speechwriters and strategists of the competing campaign teams, and in the process they look critically at the candidates, issues and tactics used in this election.

Within each of four mini-units, teachers will find warm-up activities, research tasks, final projects, and handouts, and they can add or subtract pieces or further scaffold to fit their individual classes, time frames and curricular demands. Mini-Unit 1: Who are the candidates?
Project: Candidate Profiles Students research one candidate and retool his campaign to appeal to younger voters by creating brochures, slide shows, biographies or Facebook pages or other social media strategies to introduce him. Mini-Unit 2: What are the issues?
Projects: Issue-Based Campaign Materials and Debate Students survey each other on the issues that matter to them, then research one or more of these issues in order to create campaign materials like buttons, advertising, brochures or posters around it. They then debate the issues, either from the candidates' point of view or their own. Mini-Unit 3: How are the candidates trying to win the election?
Projects: Argumentative Essay and Campaign Speech Students critique campaign ads to analyze how the candidates this year are attempting to appeal to voters, then focus on one campaign strategy to write an essay answering the question, "Which candidate is running the better campaign?" They then write campaign speeches for the candidate they have researched. Mini-Unit 4: What Do You Think?
Projects: Student Editorial and Mock Election Students conduct a one-question interview on views about the election so far, then write an editorial in which they tell why they think one of the candidates should be elected. They then use the materials they have created and what they have learned so far to run a mock election. Ten More Ideas for Teaching the Election In addition to our Election Unit, we also have ten more suggestions for how you can teach the election in your classroom. Some of these ideas are incorporated within the unit described above. 1. Create Candidate Profiles Where do the presidential candidates stand on issues? How are they represented and defined in the media, and how accurate are those portrayals? What factors, including personal characteristics like hairstyles and dress as well as campaign theme songs, contribute to the candidates' images? Create a class wiki profiling the presidential candidates. 2. Do Election Math Look at the campaign season through a mathematical lens by following the delegate count, and then use the data to make projections or by examining the role that money plays in politics by investigating whether there is a correlation between campaign donations and poll numbers. Or, using the electoral map, map out various routes to the White House by examining states populations, the number of electoral votes each state has and how many electoral votes a candidate needs to win the presidency. Then determine which combinations of states could yield a victory. Create infographics that effectively tell the story of the election thus far. Also, look into what happens if the Republican convention ends up being brokered. 3. Explore the Art of Political Speechwriting and Delivery Examine a presidential candidate's stump speech, looking specifically at word choice and how it relates to meaning and effectiveness. Then write an original stump speech for a presidential candidate that uses similar oratorical approaches as the presidential candidates themselves use in their stump speeches. Finally, create an interactive version of your speech that provides explanatory annotations about the rhetorical moves you are making and their intended effect. 4. Play Campaign News Games Play campaign bingo or conduct a scavenger hunt by finding particular pieces of campaign news in an online or print edition of the Times. 5. Explore the Issues Choose one issue of interest and examine each of the candidates' stances on the issue. Create an issue booklet or Web site that maps out and describes - and perhaps even compares - each candidate's views, platform and history on this issue. You might even include how, if at all, the candidate has evolved on the issue over time. Additionally, students can work to develop their own position on this issue and write a letter to the editor or create a video that offers their personal take on the topic. 6. Examine Debate Strategies Watch excerpts from the presidential debates, paying particular attention to candidates' rhetorical moves and commonly heard themes or phrases. Then mine the debates for examples of issue- and character-based arguments as well as spin. After analyzing candidates' approaches to debating, discuss which debate moves were the most and least effective. Hold either a mock debate in which students take on the roles of presidential candidates or a mock post-debate "spin room" session, with students playing candidate staffers. During debates, they can take advantage of the "second screen" phenomenon and monitor Facebook, Twitter and other social media to see what viewers are saying in real time. They can also try live-"tweeting" or live-blogging a debate, focusing on key phrases and moments, or pulling together a narrative of Twitter posts using a tool like Storify. 7. Investigate Polling and Projection Data Examine the results of a recent poll or a selection of recent polls, particularly ones that have accompanying graphics. Hunt for trends in the polling data. What trends exist across different groups? What opportunities do these polls point to for each of the candidates? What polling results are surprising? Write letters to the editor, or letters of advice to the political party of presidential candidate of your choice, focusing on the one or two trends in the polling data that you think are the most significant. Alternatively, examine one of Nate Silver's data analyses on his blog, FiveThirtyEight, and then discuss his analysis. On what factors does Mr. Silver base his predictions? Has he been right in the past? 8. Create a Youth Campaign Reflect on your political ideology, your stance on important campaign issues and your political party affiliation. Draw on your political identity and ideology to develop a campaign designed to get teenagers not yet eligible to vote involved in the election. For example, they might get involved in a campaign like "Why Tuesday?" or "#16tovote," or they might participate in a rally or other event. 9. Investigate Young Voters' Role Consider what young voters are saying a selection of opinion pieces written by young people about the upcoming elections and how their level of involvement so far compares with youth involvement in the 2008 election. Then conduct a series of interviews to better understand how young voters in your community are approaching the 2012 race. Create a short documentary that tells the story of how young people in your community are approaching the election. 10. Follow Campaign News Follow news of the presidential campaign on a digital or timeline, Facebook page or Twitter feed over time, and engage in class discussion along the way. Along with adding breaking news, add weekly photographs to your feed to help tell the story of the campaign and provide material for analysis. Fact-check statements made by politicians on the class page whenever they hear something questionable. On Twitter, they can use the hashtag #asknyt to submit candidate comments made during debates that they think merit some scrutiny. SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 464 words

HEADLINE: Memo to Mitt Romney: We Get It. You're Rich.

BYLINE: ANDREW ROSENTHAL


HIGHLIGHT: The presidential aspirant can't seem to stop reminding voters of his considerable wealth. 

 BODY:
Mitt Romney doesn't like it when his rivals mention his considerable personal wealth. Way back (like two months ago) in New Hampshire, he castigated Newt Gingrich for reminding voters about his career in the leveraged-buyout business. Mr. Romney called that class warfare.
I don't blame Mr. Romney for his defensiveness. Wealth is not the best selling point for a political candidate during a slow, painful recovery from a deep, painful recession - especially at a time when income inequality has reached absurd proportions. But that raises the question: Why does Mr. Romney keep telling us how rich he is?

At a debate in Iowa, Mr. Romney challenged Rick Perry (remember him?) to a $10,000 bet. I guess it didn't occur to Mr. Romney that 10K is high stakes for the average voter.
Before the New Hampshire primary he said "I like being able to fire people." Granted, this was in the context of a conversation about insurance companies, not his time at Bain. But it was a tin-eared remark nonetheless. Besides, most of us don't have the power to fire the insurance companies that our employers have selected on our behalf.
Last Friday in Michigan, while babbling about the virtues of American automobiles, he said, "My wife drives a couple of Cadillacs."
That should sew up the more-than-one-luxury-car-per-person vote.
Most recently, there was his cringe-inducing appearance at the Daytona Speedway. Mr. Romney wandered through the Nascar crowd like an anthropologist in a pith helmet observing the natives. He was trying to be Just Plain Joe, but he ended up being Just Plain Thurston Howell III. "I like those fancy raincoats you bought," he said to a group of fans wearing plastic ponchos. "Really sprung for the big bucks."
Not content with just one lame attempt at levity, Mr. Romney also recalled driving "a little fast" as a youth near his Michigan home. That would be Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, one of the wealthiest small towns in America.
When asked if he was a stock-car racing fan, Mr. Romney said, "I have some great friends who are Nascar team owners."
It's hard to know why Mr. Romney has this tic. Asked about it on Fox News, Mr. Romney said, "I just am who I am." That's a rather strange remark, coming from Mr. Romney, who's generally content to be whoever Republican primary voters want him to be.
Mr. Romney added, rather defensively: "If people think that there is something wrong with being successful in American, then they better vote for the other guy."
There is indeed nothing wrong with success. But a guy who wants to be president probably shouldn't make a habit of flaunting it.

HEADLINE: Putin Offers to Save Europe From Decline and Irrelevance

BYLINE: HARVEY MORRIS


HIGHLIGHT: Ahead of Sunday's first round of Russian elections, Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian prime minister, lambasted Western leaders in a foreign policy review. But he also tempted Europe to accept Russia's embrace in a Union of Europe that would stretch from "Lisbon to Vladivostok". 

 BODY:
LONDON - If Vladimir V. Putin, as he claims, seeks a closer relationship with the rest of Europe, he is going about achieving it in a funny way.
The Russian prime minister, apparently headed for a return to the presidency according to polls ahead of the first round of elections scheduled for Sunday, has done little to endear himself to his country's western neighbors during the campaign.
Aside from highlighting deep divisions over Syria and Iran, Mr. Putin has been taking pot shots at European energy policy and attacking European governments for failing to lift visa requirements on Russians. Nearer to home, his government appears to be gearing up for a new "gas war" with Ukraine.
Odd timing, then, to come up with a vision for a Union of Europe - not to be confused with the 27-member European Union - that would stretch from "Lisbon to Vladivostok."
The idea figured in a lengthy peroration on foreign policy that Mr. Putin published on Monday. It portrayed the rest of Europe - once "an oasis of stability and order" - as an economic basket case whose problems could not but affect Russia's interests.
With the tone of a distant if kindly uncle, Mr Putin wrote: "We are by no means indifferent to developments in united Europe." Russia was already involved in international efforts to support Europe's ailing economies, and was "not opposed in principle to direct financial assistance in some cases."
The concept of a Union of Europe, a phrase Mr. Putin ascribed to Russian experts, was not a new one. Nor was its objective: a strengthened alliance with the rest of Europe that would reinforce Russia's position between the United States and the emerging powers of Asia.
Sergei Karaganov, a political analyst and former deputy director of European studies at the Russian Academy of Sciences, wrote in 2010 under the title: "A Union of Europe: The Last Chance?":
"If Europe does not unite, it will be the U.S. and China that will call the tune in the future world, and the brilliant half-millennium of Europe will be over."
Igor Yurgens, an adviser to Dmitri A. Medvedev, the outgoing president, made a similar argument back in 2008 when he wrote: "If isolated from one another, and of course in a climate of rivalry between Russia and Europe, neither will be able to claim a role of a first-class center of strength in the future world order comparable with the U.S. or China, instead becoming objects of politics of external forces."
There's little indication that Europe's present leaders want to jump aboard Mr. Putin's Union of Europe bandwagon. Like their historic predecessors, they are reluctant to be embraced by the Russian bear. As Mr. Putin's warnings about Europe's energy policies indicate, Russia can prove a coercive suitor.
Catherine Ashton, the European Union's High Representative for foreign affairs, is among those not so easily wooed. In a speech this month, she decried another job swap between the Russian president and prime minister that "made many Russian citizens feel that things were being decided between only two men, over the heads of voters."
If anyone needed help, it was not Europe but Russia itself, she suggested. "We will continue our support to modernize both Russia's economic basis and the foundations for a dynamic society oriented towards the future," she said.

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: Prominent Democrat Endorses Third-Party Group

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: David Boren, a former Democratic senator and governor from Oklahoma who backed President Obama in 2008, is endorsing Americans Elect to provide "electric shock therapy" to the political system. 

 BODY:
Even as Republicans wage a bitter, intra-party feud for the right to challenge President Obama, a group called Americans Elect is steadily building support - and a 50-state infrastructure - for a bipartisan ticket that could challenge both parties for the White House.
That effort will get a fresh push on Tuesday from David Boren, a former Democratic senator and governor from Oklahoma who backed Mr. Obama in 2008 but says he is now looking for a way to provide "electric shock therapy" to the political system.
"The country is going to really be in deep trouble if we don't act soon," Mr. Boren, who is now president of the University of Oklahoma, said in an interview with The Caucus. "I think this is really a cry from many of us who are really concerned for the future of the country."
Mr. Boren is part of a small, but growing cadre of politicians from both sides of the aisle who are expressing displeasure with the political system - and the political gridlock it is producing. Just last week, Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah and candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, voiced support for a third party, saying that the two-party system was broken. 
The negative and personal character attacks being flung by the Republican presidential candidates is adding to Mr. Boren's outrage at the process. On Tuesday, he will announce that he is endorsing the Americans Elect effort.
Asnoted earlier by Richard W. Stevenson in The New York Times, the Americans Elect group is planning to nominate a bipartisan ticket -- a presidential candidate from one party and a vice-presidential running mate from
another -- in the hopes of returning to an era when the two parties worked effectively together.
An online process will choose six finalists in May, each of whom will pick a running mate from another party. And then online voting will conclude in June with a two-person ticket that organizers say will be on the ballot in all 50 states in November.
Officials at the group said Monday that they had collected 2.4 million signatures and have ensured a place on the ballot in 16 states, including California. They have finished collecting signatures in another 13 states and say they are confident in their success. Mr. Boren's comments on Tuesday will come as the group presents its signatures to get on the ballot in his home state of Oklahoma.
But logistical concerns are only part of the battle. To have an impact, the Americans Elect effort must earn the respect and the blessings of big-name, establishment figures in both parties who are willing to risk the ire of their friends and colleagues by considering the possibility of a third ticket.
Mr. Boren took pains to say that his endorsement of Americans Elect does not mean that he necessarily will support the group's presidential ticket.
"If Americans Elect produces a ticket that is not well qualified, that I don't think has the strength to bring the country together, it's certainly possible that I would support President Obama's re-election," Mr. Boren said.
But that sentiment alone is likely to be seen as a blunt message by Mr. Obama's re-election team in Chicago.
Mr. Boren served as a Democratic governor in the late 1970s and then was a Democratic senator from 1979 to 1994. He currently serves as the co-chair of Mr. Obama's Intelligence Advisory Board. He praised Mr. Obama's national security successes and said that his endorsement of the Americans Elect group is not meant as a criticism of the president.
But at the same time, he said he no longer had any confidence that electing either a Democratic or Republican ticket would restore the sense of political comity that prevailed during much of his time in the Senate.
"What we have really seen is the inability of either party to reach across the aisle as we used to and reach a meeting of the minds," he said. "The most important ability the next president must have is to really bring the two parties together and make the two-party system work again in a way that it did 20 or 25 years ago."
There is deep suspicion among Republican and Democratic strategists that the Americans Elect effort is secretly aimed at helping one party or the other.
Mr. Boren said his friends in both parties had whispered to him their conspiracy theories. Republicans tell him the group is part of a plot to re-elect Mr. Obama. Democrats tell him they believe it's a front group to put a Republican in the White House next year.
"It's neither," he said, adding that he found interesting the "knee-jerk" reactions from both sides.
Mr. Boren said he had no interest in being on a ticket himself. And he declined to offer names of some people he said he knew to be considering running under the group's banner in the fall. But, he said, "I would be surprised if we did not have people who would be viewed as highly experienced."
"There are some very serious people thinking about entering the race through this process," he said.
Among the people who are often mentioned is Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire mayor of New York who dropped his Republican affiliation several years ago to become an independent. Mr. Bloomberg and his aides have long played coy about the possibility of a presidential run.
Others already involved in the group or mentioned as possible candidates include Christine Todd Whitman, a moderate Republican who served as governor of New Jersey, and Erskine Bowles, who served as White House chief of staff under Bill Clinton and was the president of the University of North Carolina for five years.
Buddy Roemer, who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican presidential nomination, announced this month that he would seek to lead the Americans Elect ticket this year.
The group says that more than 2.6 million people have visited its Web site and that about 380,000 people have signed up to be "delegates" to the online convention that will pick the presidential ticket in June. The group has 460,000 Facebook fans.
Mr. Boren said that his discussions with the organizers of Americans Elect suggested that they shared a desire for a ticket that would embrace long-term fiscal reform, seek to pass a constitutional amendment to bar corporate contributions to politicians and appoint a bipartisan cabinet once elected.
But he conceded that the online community could choose a different kind of ticket that he would be unable to support.
"It could happen, and if it does, it wouldn't be something that I support," Mr. Boren said.
But he said that even if the Americans Elect ticket failed to win in November, the impact on the two major parties could be impressive. He said the mere presence of a third option for voters might encourage the creation of a bipartisan caucus in the Congress and a new willingness to work together.
"The American people have been saying, 'We wish we had a third choice, we wish we had a third way,'" Mr. Boren said. The question is, he added, "Are they really going to vote that way?"

HEADLINE: After Michigan and Arizona? More Angst

BYLINE: FRANK BRUNI


HIGHLIGHT: Even if Tuesday goes largely Romney's way, he'll be dogged by the sense that he still hasn't truly proven that he can engender enthusiasm where it doesn't naturally exist and where he doesn't enjoy a particular advantage. 

 BODY:
Cruising the Internet for campaign updates last weekend, I stumbled across this headline on the Politico web site, which wasn't the only one to trumpet the, um, news: "Daniels says he's a no."
At long last, clarity! Because the previous 27 times that Mitch Daniels, the governor of Indiana, had said he wouldn't jump into the presidential fray didn't really count. On one of those occasions, after all, he had crossed his heart but hadn't hoped to die. On another, he seemed to wink, or at least subsequent forensic analysis of video footage of the moment suggested that possibility. And on none of them had the Republican Party's situation devolved to so desperate a point.
So Republicans were still wishing. And reporters were still asking. 
And the results today from Michigan and Arizona are unlikely to put an end to that, no matter what they are.
Let's say Rick Santorum wins Michigan, if only by a percentage point. The panic already gripping the Republican Party will deepen and spread, because Santorum's chance to actually seize the nomination will look more plausible than ever. But he remains the longest of long shots to beat President Obama down the line. An economic calamity might get him there, because an economic calamity might get any Republican nominee there, but barring that? He's a potent turnoff to swing voters, who find many of his stances on social issues archaic and mean, for the simple reason that they are. And to moderate Republicans, he's an embarrassment. So they will keep fantasizing-and reporters will keep hypothesizing-about some last-minute intervention or convention hijinks to save the party from his potentially devastating impact on it.
Let's say Romney wins Michigan, and does it by four or five points. It will be said-rightly-that that's no better a result than he should always have been able to manage. Michigan, after all, is as close to a home state as he has. He went to high school there, and his father was once its popular governor. What's more, he won the state's Republican primary in 2008 by nine percentage points over John McCain. He can't do as well four years later?
Even if Tuesday goes largely Romney's way, he'll be dogged by the sense that he still hasn't truly proven that he can engender enthusiasm where it doesn't naturally exist and where he doesn't enjoy a particular advantage.
A victory in Arizona, like his victory in Nevada, would in small measure reflect-and to a certain degree be interpreted in terms of-a pronounced Mormon presence in the state. As the New York Times's Nate Silver noted in a recent post his FiveThirtyEight blog:
In the 2008 primary there, Mormon voters constituted 11 percent of the electorate - and Romney won 88 percent of their votes, versus 8 percent for John McCain.
If Romney posts similar numbers among Mormon voters this year in Tuesday's primary - and there's no reason to think that he won't - that works out a nine-point built-in advantage in the state. 
Indeed, most of his victories in the primaries so far have prosaic explanations other than the sheer hubba-hubba of his appeal. New Hampshire? It's something of a home state, too: he has a house there. Florida? He outspent Newt Gingrich five to one, unleashing a merciless barrage of attack ads. 
Michigan and Arizona victories wouldn't end the sense that Romney hasn't yet closed the deal. Questions would endure, as would many Republicans' disappointment in the awkwardness of his candidacy and their worry, based on what they've seen so far this year, that he'd bumble and misspeak his way into certain defeat by Obama.
The run-up to Michigan wasn't exactly reassuring. There was the "couple of Cadillacs" comment. There was the remark about not knowing much about the sport of NASCAR but having "some great friends that are NASCAR team owners."
In law they talk about "excited utterances," which are exceptions to the hearsay prohibition. Romney is bedeviled by "affluent utterances," which threaten to become nails in the coffin of his candidacy. Despite all the grief they cause, he can't stop making asides that are big bay windows into his remarkable riches. And that's not the best view to give voters at this particular moment in the American story, when joblessness remains high, the rebound from a slump remains tentative and there's more discussion than in a very long time about disparities in wealth and inequities in the tax code.
So tomorrow and later this week and possibly into next, when Super Tuesday does or doesn't start to settle what's left unsettled after Michigan, there will be stubborn dreams of Daniels. And persistent mirages of Chris Christie. And prayers said for help from Jeb Bush, who just six months ago was thought to have too much of a whiff of dynasty around him and to be too soon a reminder of a presidency that disappointed so many.
In the context of the current Republican field, he's suddenly an electoral ideal, a knight in shining Kennebunkport corduroys. That's where we're at.

SECTION: US

LENGTH: 604 words

HEADLINE: Without Reference to 'Snobs' or 'Indoctrination,' Santorum Supported College Access in 2006

BYLINE: TANYA CALDWELL


HIGHLIGHT: When running for Senate in 2006, Rick Santorum called for every Pennsylvanian to have access to higher education. 

 BODY:
It seems that Rick Santorum, a former senator from Pennsylvania who faces tough Republican primary battles Tuesday in Michigan and Arizona, shared some of President Obama's higher-education goals -- at least in 2006.
Mr. Santorum was speaking to a Tea Party group in Michigan on Saturday when he called Mr. Obama a "snob" for supporting higher education for all Americans.
But when he was running for the United States Senate in 2006, Mr. Santorum wanted all Pennsylvanians to go to college, according to Talking Points Memo, which posted a screen shot of the candidate's "commitment to higher education" from his 2006 campaign Web site.
"In addition to Rick's support of ensuring that primary and secondary schools in Pennsylvania are equipped for success, he is equally committed to ensuring (that) every Pennsylvanian has access to higher education," the site reads. "Rick Santorum has supported legislative solutions that provide loans, grants and tax incentives to make higher education more accessible and affordable."
The campaign site's use of the word "access" appears consistent with Mr. Obama's "Education Blueprint for an Economy Built to Last," which states that the United States is being outpaced internationally and suffers from a domestic "college attainment gap," and cites higher education as a "prerequisite for the growing jobs of the new economy."
As part of his continued focus on education, President Obama has presented an agenda that will ensure that America's students and workers receive the education and training needed for the jobs of today and tomorrow. The president's plan reflects a commitment to keeping the American promise alive by advancing educational opportunity that will lead to good jobs that pay well and provide greater security for the middle class.
Regaining America's global leadership in higher education attainment requires robust participation and effort to meet this goal from all colleges and universities - public and private, two-year and four-year, across all states and territories.
Mr. Obama has also called on all Americans to obtain at least one year of higher education or career training, whether at a community college, a four-year school, an apprenticeship or vocational training.
Last week, Mr. Santorum called Mr. Obama's higher-education goals a way to get people into "indoctrination mills" led by liberal professors. But a former professor of Mr. Santorum's told The New Republic that the candidate (who went to college and has three degrees) was never at a disadvantage for having conservative views.
The Choice has reached out to Mr. Santorum's campaign for comment, and will update this post if we receive a response.
Meanwhile, Mr. Obama rejected the indoctrination charge in remarks to the nation's governors at the White House on Monday.
"When I speak about higher education, we are not just talking about a four-year degree," he said. "We are talking about somebody going to a community college and getting trained for that manufacturing job that now is requiring someone walking through the door handling a million-dollar piece of equipment. And they can't go in there unless they have some basic training beyond what they received in high school."
Mr. Santorum's campaign seemed to back away from the "snob" comment on Monday, Michael D. Shear reported in The Caucus, The Times' political news blog.
Alice Stewart, the spokeswoman, said she was encouraged by Mr. Obama's encouragement of trade or vocational schools. 
"We're glad that the president clarified that after Rick pointed that out," Ms. Stewart said on MSNBC. "That's exactly what Rick was saying."

HEADLINE: To Autoworkers, Obama Turns Up Oratory

BYLINE: HELENE COOPER


HIGHLIGHT: President Obama was in full campaign mode and resembled his 2008 self in a rousing speech at a United Auto Workers conference in Washington. 

 BODY:
In case there are any Michigan voters who haven't heard, President Obama had this message on Tuesday morning as the state's primary got underway: three years ago, he helped save the auto industry with a controversial bailout.
Mr. Obama highlighted this decision during a rousing speech to the United Auto Workers conference in Washington. The president was in full campaign mode, resembled his 2008 self, throughout his address, which was conveniently timed as Michigan voters were headed to the polls.
"Just a few years ago, nearly one in five autoworkers were handed a pink slip," Mr. Obama said. "And as the financial crisis hit with its full fury, America faced a hard and once unimaginable reality: two of the Big Three - G.M. and Chrysler - were on the brink of failure."
And then, he got to the punch-line that he has been perfecting ever since the Republican campaign road-show headed to Michigan, where Mitt Romney has been trying to live down an Op-Ed piece he wrote in The New York Times in 2008 headlined "Let Detroit Go Bankrupt."
Mr. Obama has been gleefully bringing that up at just about every public event. His speech Tuesday, before a raucous crowd of the Democratic Party's labor base, gave him the ultimate platform. "Some politicians," Mr. Obama said, "even said we should 'let Detroit go bankrupt!'"
The crowd booed. Mr. Obama paused, dramatically.
"You remember that?" he said.
More boos.
Another pause, then Mr. Obama started grinning, clearly enjoying himself. "Think about what that choice would have meant for this country, if we had turned our backs on you, if America had thrown in the towel. G.M. and Chrysler wouldn't exist today."
Mr. Obama, when he chooses to and as he did consistently in 2008 during his run for president, can turn up the oratory. The crowd of autoworkers and labor leaders were eating up every word - and their energy appeared to further amp up Mr. Obama. The president fed them one line after another, and several times detoured from his prepared remarks, like when he gave an endorsement for the new Chevy Volt that included a promise to buy one - in five years time, of course.
"I got to sit in a Chevy Volt, even though Secret Service wouldn't let me drive it," Mr. Obama said, to cheers. "I enjoyed sitting in it. And four or five years from now when I'm not president no more and I can drive myself, I'm gonna buy one."
From the crowd came the chant every president likes to hear: "Four more years! Four more years!" Mr. Obama broke into another beaming smile.
It was with that smile still stretched across his face that he - again - went after Mr. Romney, although never mentioning him by name. "It's been fun watching these folks trying to completely rewrite history now that you're back on your feet," he told the autoworkers.
He went into a long riff about the hard labors of union workers, and sought to turn Republican rhetoric about American values against the party. "Let me tell you, I keep hearing people talk about values all the time," Mr. Obama said, his voice rising. "Hard work, that's a value."
Mr. Obama even channeled Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who died in 2009. "He used to say, 'What is it about working men and women they find so offensive?'"
Mr. Obama's campaign advisers had been enjoying Rick Santorum's rise in the polls in Michigan, and say that even as Mr. Romney has surged back in that state - the state he grew up in - they have gleaned important tips for the general election. At the top of that list, they say, will be looking for more ways to beat up Mr. Romney for writing that Op-Ed in 2008.
Not surprisingly, Republicans were quick to respond Tuesday.
"President Obama is known for putting his re-election over keeping his promises to the American people," said Kirsten Kukowski, a spokeswoman with the Republican National Committee. "Obama's speech to U.A.W. today is no different. This is an insider deal for his union cronies who got billions in bailout money and are now backing Obama's re-election campaign."

HEADLINE: Putin Offers to Save Europe From Decline and Irrelevance

BYLINE: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE


HIGHLIGHT: Ahead of Sunday's first round of Russian elections, Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian prime minister, lambasted Western leaders in a foreign policy review. But he also tempted Europe to accept Russia's embrace in a Union of Europe that would stretch from "Lisbon to Vladivostok". 

 BODY:
LONDON - If Vladimir V. Putin, as he claims, seeks a closer relationship with the rest of Europe, he is going about achieving it in a funny way.
The Russian prime minister, apparently headed for a return to the presidency according to polls ahead of the first round of elections scheduled for Sunday, has done little to endear himself to his country's western neighbors during the campaign.
Aside from highlighting deep divisions over Syria and Iran, Mr. Putin has been taking pot shots at European energy policy and attacking European governments for failing to lift visa requirements on Russians. Nearer to home, his government appears to be gearing up for a new "gas war" with Ukraine.
Odd timing, then, to come up with a vision for a Union of Europe - not to be confused with the 27-member European Union - that would stretch from "Lisbon to Vladivostok."
The idea figured in a lengthy peroration on foreign policy that Mr. Putin published on Monday. It portrayed the rest of Europe - once "an oasis of stability and order" - as an economic basket case whose problems could not but affect Russia's interests.
With the tone of a distant if kindly uncle, Mr Putin wrote: "We are by no means indifferent to developments in united Europe." Russia was already involved in international efforts to support Europe's ailing economies, and was "not opposed in principle to direct financial assistance in some cases."
The concept of a Union of Europe, a phrase Mr. Putin ascribed to Russian experts, was not a new one. Nor was its objective: a strengthened alliance with the rest of Europe that would reinforce Russia's position between the United States and the emerging powers of Asia.
Sergei Karaganov, a political analyst and former deputy director of European studies at the Russian Academy of Sciences, wrote in 2010 under the title: "A Union of Europe: The Last Chance?":
"If Europe does not unite, it will be the U.S. and China that will call the tune in the future world, and the brilliant half-millennium of Europe will be over."
Igor Yurgens, an adviser to Dmitri A. Medvedev, the outgoing president, made a similar argument back in 2008 when he wrote: "If isolated from one another, and of course in a climate of rivalry between Russia and Europe, neither will be able to claim a role of a first-class center of strength in the future world order comparable with the U.S. or China, instead becoming objects of politics of external forces."
There's little indication that Europe's present leaders want to jump aboard Mr. Putin's Union of Europe bandwagon. Like their historic predecessors, they are reluctant to be embraced by the Russian bear. As Mr. Putin's warnings about Europe's energy policies indicate, Russia can prove a coercive suitor.
Catherine Ashton, the European Union's High Representative for foreign affairs, is among those not so easily wooed. In a speech this month, she decried another job swap between the Russian president and prime minister that "made many Russian citizens feel that things were being decided between only two men, over the heads of voters."
If anyone needed help, it was not Europe but Russia itself, she suggested. "We will continue our support to modernize both Russia's economic basis and the foundations for a dynamic society oriented towards the future," she said.

HEADLINE: For Companies, Tax Code Adds to Debt's Appeal

BYLINE: STEVEN M. DAVIDOFF


HIGHLIGHT: While the president's review of corporate taxation looked at the tax advantages of debt, it had no proposals to change the situation, probably because that would cause uncertainty and complications. 

 BODY:
Corporate America's love affair with debt is driven by a heavy subsidy, courtesy of the federal tax code. It's an unhealthy preference that the Obama administration is now reviewing.
The problem arises because the interest that corporations pay on their debt is deductible on their federal taxes.
To understand the effect of this deduction, imagine if you could deduct the interest you pay on your debt. I am not just talking about the deduction on your home mortgage. This would be a deduction for all of the interest paid on your credit card bills, auto loans and any other loans you had, including the one from Uncle Mikey.
What would be the effect? First, you would have more money in your pocket. That 10- or 15-something percent interest rate on your credit card would be effectively reduced by up to a third, depending upon your tax rate.
But because debt is now cheaper, you may be more likely to borrow to make purchases rather than purchase items outright. If so, you would end up taking on more aggregate debt and saving less. Before the 1986 tax overhaul, credit card interest could in fact be deducted. Congress eliminated this loophole, in part, because members thought it encouraged just this sort of behavior.
This is what is occurring in corporate America. Companies can finance investment from either debt or equity. But profit on an investment financed with equity - stock issued by the company - is taxed. In contrast, if the project is financed with debt, then only the profit after interest payments are made is taxed. This means debt-financed investments are cheaper than equity.
This creates a bias by corporations toward debt.
The big winners are capital-intensive industries that rely heavily on debt to finance their operations, like utilities and manufacturers. But companies owned by private equity firms also benefit substantially since they borrow substantial amounts of cash in buyouts.
The debt bias is even greater when you take into account the tax deduction for rapid depreciation of investment. The Treasury estimates that corporations pay an effective marginal tax rate of 37 percent, allowing for depreciation, when they issue stock to invest in goods and equipment. In contrast, if a company finances the purchase with debt, the effective marginal tax rate is minus 60 percent when the effect of accelerated depreciation is taken into account. This means that for every $100 of debt taken on and invested, the effective tax deduction is $160. But for equity, the company and its investors pay $37.
Compare this with tax-friendly Ireland, where the effective marginal tax rate is 15 percent for an equity investment in equipment, but minus 4 percent when the investment is financed with debt. Or Japan, where the tax rate rises to 49 percent for equity and is also minus 4 percent for debt financing.
Some complain that the base tax rate of 35 percent in the United States is too high. But in the case of debt and depreciation, the United States is a world leader. The United States tax subsidy for debt when depreciation is taken into account is almost triple the average for the Group of 7 and other developed countries.
While overall United States corporate debt levels have fallen over the years, it is not hard to conclude that the tax code is creating incentives for companies to take on more debt than they otherwise would. The extra debt can lead to higher bankruptcy rates, higher administration costs and excessive risk-taking. Too much debt can make recessions last longer as companies struggle to shake off their burden.
When President Obama announced his proposal on the corporate tax code, much of the attention was on the suggested reduction in the corporate tax rate, to 28 percent from 35 percent.
But Mr. Obama's proposal also recognized that "outsized reliance on debt financing can increase the risk of financial distress and thus raise the likelihood of bankruptcy." But the proposal does not address whether to eliminate the interest tax deduction.
Wouldn't that be the simple answer to the problem?
Nothing is ever simple in taxes, alas. Eliminating the interest tax deduction may reduce investment, and result in country arbitrage as companies shift debt and equity to offshore subsidiaries with more favorable tax regimes.
A report last year from the International Monetary Fundsuggested that the debt bias be eliminated by allowing companies to have an equivalent deduction for equity. But giving a tax deduction for equity would only make things more complex because companies would then argue over how equity should be valued for the deduction. And overall corporate tax rates would probably have to rise to account for this adjustment.
The International Monetary Fund's recommendation was in line with that of a bipartisan panel established by President George W. Bush in 2005, which proposed putting debt and equity on equal footing for tax purposes.
The fund's report also examined why the debt tax deduction might be appropriate. Banks are generally less willing to lend to corporations because they have insufficient information about them. A debt tax deduction can make borrowing easier for companies.
Moreover, there are reasons to allow corporations, but not people, to deduct debt. The tax deduction on debt comes about because corporations are taxed only on their earnings. The interest paid is subtracted from their earnings. Corporations are not using this debt to finance their day-to-day operations as people might; this is debt taken on to make investments.
It is the uncertainty and complications surrounding an elimination of the debt tax deduction that probably kept the Obama administration from proposing a solution. No doubt, the administration is also positioning itself for hard bargaining ahead. And realistically the chance of any tax overhaul's occurring before the election is about the same as that of an outbreak of world peace.
The president did hint at which course he prefers, however. The report focused on how the United States is oversubsidizing debt compared with other nations, establishing a case for cutting back the debt deduction to put it on parity with those of other countries. This option was also laid out by his Economic Recovery Advisory Board in its 2010 report on tax reform. In that case, only a portion of debt would be tax deductible rather than all of it.
This seems a sensible place to start, reducing the huge subsidy for debt to bring the United States more in line with other nations. This is one area of the global economy where the United States may be too competitive. Subsidizing corporate debt is just too risky.

HEADLINE: Live Blogging Michigan and Arizona Primaries

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Times is providing live updates and analysis from the Republican primaries in Michigan and Arizona. 

 BODY:
The race for the Republican presidential nomination is not likely to be settled on Tuesday, though much is at stake for Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as voters in Michigan and Arizona head to the polls. The race in Michigan remains tight and its delegates are likely to be split between the two main rivals, but the state is an important one for Mr. Romney, who was born and raised there, and won it convincingly in 2008. It also offers Mr. Santorum - and skeptical conservatives - the best chance yet to turn nagging questions about Mr. Romney into deep doubts about his candidacy. 
Arizona is a different story. Mr. Romney has been building support in the state for months, aided by an endorsement from Senator John McCain and the state's significant Mormon population, which voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Romney in 2008. Though Mr. Santorum made an aggressive push there last week, late polling suggests its 29 delegates are out of his reach. 
The Times is covering Tuesday's contests and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.

6:57 P.M. | Exit Polls: Evangelicals and Catholics
The evangelical Christian vote has been somewhat all over the map in this year's nominating contests. Exit poll results showed Mr. Romney winning white evangelical voters in Nevada, Mr. Gingrich winning them in South Carolina, and the evangelical vote dividing between Mr. Romney and Mr. Gingrich in Florida. Earlier, in Iowa, Rick Santorum won a plurality of white evangelicals.
(There were no exit or entrance polls in the Colorado, Missouri, Minnesota contests that Mr. Santorum swept earlier this month.) 
Intensifying his pursuit of socially conservative voters in recent days, Mr. Santorum, who is Catholic, defended the role of religion in public life this weekend, dismissing John F. Kennedy's call for the separation of religion and politics, and saying that college campuses in America are not a "neutral setting" for people of faith.
In Michigan, nearly 4 in 10 primary voters are white Christian evangelicals, according to early exit poll results, and about 3 in 10 are Catholic.
Catholic voters made up at least about third of voters in both New Hampshire and Florida - and in both of those states, they swung for Mr. Romney.
But only about 1 in 7 voters in Michigan said that abortion mattered most to their vote today. Even among social conservatives, the economy was the No. 1 issue - nearly half of white evangelical voters said the economy mattered most to their decision, with nearly a quarter saying either abortion or the deficit mattered the most.

6:32 P.M. | Romney Looks to Win Conservative Voters
When Mr. Romney won Nevada's caucus on the heels of another victory in Florida, his campaign argued that he had finally made inroads with voters who call themselves very conservative.
In fact, in Nevada, Mr. Romney finally won that category, capturing 46 percent of the "very conservative" vote, while Mr. Gingrich only took 25 percent and Mr. Santorum (who did not campaign much there) took 15 percent.
But was that a fluke? Many of those who said they were very conservative also were Mormons, a group much more inclined to vote for Mr. Romney, who is a Mormon.
And a few days later, Mr. Romney got walloped in Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota. Exit and entrance polling was not available, but Mr. Santorum's campaign claimed credit for scoring big among the most conservative voters in those states.
Now, watching how those voters cast their ballots in Michigan and Arizona will be very interesting.
In Michigan, Mr. Santorum should have an edge. He has been talking at length about social issues, speaking in the kind of language that helps to fire up the Tea Party and evangelical bases of the Republican Party.
Arizona might be a bit different. The candidates have spent less time there, and immigration is a bigger deal in the border state. How does that cut for very conservative voters? That's unclear. Mr. Romney has tacked sharply to the right on the issue of illegal immigration, but Mr. Santorum is no liberal on the issue either.
The results of the "very conservative" block are probably of greater importance for Mr. Romney, who still faces questions about his ability to excite that kind of voter. If he improves tonight, that will help his campaign going forward.

6:22 P.M. | Exit Polls: Enthusiasm Gap in Arizona
An indicator of the lack of enthusiasm for the candidates on the ballot, half of Republican primary voters in Arizona said they strongly favored the candidate for whom they had just voted. Additionally, only about three in four said they would definitely vote for the Republican nominee in November. Among supporters of Mr. Paul, this figure was about one in three.
Only a bare majority of Arizona Republican primary voters said they had a favorable impression of Mr. McCain, the Republican nominee in the 2008 presidential election. Mr. McCain's tepid favorability suggests that his endorsement of Mr. Romney may not be influential. 
Three in five Arizona Republican primary voters said that working in business better prepared a candidate to serve as president than working in government. This was also the dominant view among supporters of every candidate except for Mr. Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, whose supporters were more favorable toward government experience.
Nearly half of Arizona voters said that last week's debate was an important factor in their vote.
- 
6:09 P.M. | Exit Polls: The Economy Wins Again
As was the case in every previous exit poll conducted in this nomination race, voters in the Arizona Republican primary overwhelmingly picked the economy as their No. 1 issue in deciding whom to support (about half of all responses). The second biggest issue cited by voters was the budget deficit (about one-third of responses). The economy was the top issue concern for supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, but supporters of Ron Paul felt that the budget deficit was more important.
Also repeating the pattern found in other exit polls this season, Arizona Republican primary voters said that the most important candidate quality was the ability to beat Mr. Obama (nearly two in five responses). While this was true among supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, supporters of Mr. Paul were more likely to say that being a true conservative was the candidate quality they prized most (about one in three responses). 
Half of Republican primary goers in Arizona said that a candidate sharing their religious beliefs was somewhat or greatly important to their vote. 
Just as in 2008, about one in five voters said they believed abortion should be illegal in all cases.
While 40 percent of Republican primary voters in Florida said that most illegal immigrants working in the United States should be offered a chance to apply for citizenship, in Arizona this option received the support of only one in three - about equal to the number saying they should be deported.

6:01 P.M. | Santorum and Female Voters
Has Mr. Santorum angered women?
For the past week, Mr. Santorum has been taking positions that might turn off some women, especially independents from the suburbs. He focused on contraception for days and over the weekend called Mr. Obama a "snob" for advocating on behalf of college.
Those are subjects that may fire up Mr. Santorum's base, but they threaten to depress his vote among women, particularly in the parts of Michigan that are more moderate.
So the question will be whether women will decide they would rather support Mr. Romney, and whether that support will be enough to help overcome Mr. Romney's other weaknesses.
If that gender gap between the two candidates begins to widen as the night progresses, Mr. Santorum could find himself on the losing side tonight.

5:58 P.M. | Exit Polls: College Graduates and Union Members
How well will Mr. Santorum's remarks about President Obama's being a "snob" about college education go over in Michigan, and who were his targets? 
Today's exit polls showed that about half of Michigan primary voters held a college degree, and about 3 in 10 had attended some college or held an associate's degree. In Florida, New Hampshire and Nevada, most college graduates supported Mr. Romney, while they were more divided in Iowa and South Carolina.
Michigan also has one of the highest union membership rates in the country. In today's primary, early exit poll results showed about one-quarter of voters said there was a union member in their household, and about one in seven said they were a union member themselves. In 2008, union households broke evenly for Mr. McCain and Mr. Romney.
- 
5:53 P.M. | Exit Polls: In Michigan, a More Moderate Electorate
With the first waves of exit polls in from voters in Michigan and Arizona, the state of Michigan has a slightly more moderate electorate than some previous Republican caucus and primary contests in 2012.
About 6 in 10 primary voters in Michigan consider themselves conservative, with about 3 in 10 saying they are very conservative and about the same number saying they are moderate, according to preliminary exit poll results.
One reason that Republican primary voters in Michigan may appear less conservative than other early nominating contests is that Michigan does not require voters to be registered Republicans, so anyone, including independents and Democrats, can temporarily call himself or herself a Republican and enter the voting booth.
And at least one candidate is taking advantage of that flexibility to try to improve his chances.
Mr. Romney has called Mr. Santorum's automated phone call lobbying Democrats to vote against Mr. Romney a "dirty trick." But Mr. Romney himself has admitted to voting in a Democratic primary as a registered independent, for Paul Tsongas, whom he thought would make the weakest Democratic presidential candidate in 1992.
So did Democrats really come out to vote in the Republican contest more than usual today? It's hard to say: Exit poll results showed that about 1 in 10 voters in Michigan today said they usually think of themselves as a Democrat. In 2008, 7 percent of Republican primary voters identified as Democrat, and in 2000, 17 percent did.
Of the other early nominating contests with exit polls, New Hampshire, which Mr. Romney won handily, had the most moderate electorate, with just 22 percent of voters saying they were very conservative, and a slim majority saying they were conservative.
In Nevada and Iowa, more than 8 in 10 voters said they were conservative, and nearly half of all primary voters said they were very conservative. Nearly 7 in 10 voters in South Carolina and Florida considered themselves conservative.
- 
5:26 P.M. | Video: Primary Day
- 
5:30 P.M. | Arizona Looks Like Less of a Nail-Biter
There are 29 delegates at stake in Arizona, and the Republicans gathered there last week for what was being billed as the last debate of the Republican contest. But in the end, the contest there is ending up as something of an afterthought, overshadowed by the fight going on in Michigan on Tuesday. The candidates have barely been in the state since the debate.
One reason? Polls suggest that this will be an easy win for Mr. Romney, the former Massachusetts governor. For what it's worth, he received the endorsement of Jan Brewer, the Republican governor of Arizona, last week, and has the backing of Senator John McCain. And the state has a sizable population of Mormons - Mr. Romney is a Mormon - who turned out at the campaign rallies he held during his last visit to the state last week.
Unlike Michigan, this is a closed primary, meaning that only registered Republicans are permitted to vote. Polls close at 9 p.m. Eastern time. In 2008, the primary was won by Mr. McCain in what was also something less than a nail-biter.
- 
5:28 P.M. | Could Early Voters Turn Michigan?
As the Michigan votes start rolling in tonight, keep an eye on the votes that were cast before today.
Early voting rewards campaigns that are highly organized, like Mr. Romney's. They can identify voters that might support a candidate, make sure they get an early ballot, and follow up to make sure voters fill out and returns their ballot.
The expectation is that Mr. Romney's campaign has done well in early voting in Michigan. That could give him an early lead as the voting gets under way. But that lead could evaporate if Mr. Santorum's election-day voters turn out in much larger numbers.
Early voting has already made a difference in the 2012 campaign. Mr. Romney's campaign methodically pushed his supporters in Florida to vote early, helping him defeat Newt Gingrich during the primary there at the end of last month.
Will it make the same difference in Michigan? We should know soon enough.
- 
5:13 P.M. | Setting the Stage in Michigan and Arizona
The intensity of the rhetorical battle between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum before the primaries in Michigan and Arizona would suggest that a denouement might finally be at hand.
But it's possible that little will be settled Tuesday night.
In part, that's because the race in Michigan appears to be very close; a matter of just a few thousand votes could separate the victor from his nearest competitor. Winning by a hair will hardly confer unstoppable momentum.
There's also the delegate count. Almost all of Michigan's delegates are awarded at the district level: two delegates for the winner of each Congressional district. The rules raise the real possibility that the winner of the popular vote could be on the losing end of the delegate tally.
And finally, there's Arizona. A decisive win there for Mr. Romney - who is far ahead in the state polls, even as he struggles in Michigan - would muddle the political picture from the two contests even further.

HEADLINE: Parsing the Exit Polls in Michigan and Arizona

BYLINE: ALLISON KOPICKI and DAVID R. JONES


HIGHLIGHT: Highlights so far, based on surveys of voters leaving the primary polls: a moderate electorate in Michigan and an enthusiasm gap in Arizona. 

 BODY:
10:37 p.m. | Updated 

Santorum Strong with Conservatives in Michigan
Leading up to today's primaries, Rick Santorum campaigned heavily in Michigan, but spent little time or money in Arizona, and that bet showed at the polls.
According to exit poll results, Mr. Santorum found strength among a number of key groups in Michigan to rival Mitt Romney in his home state: union households, strong supporters of the Tea Party, white evangelical Christians and those who consider themselves very conservative.
He also held a strong advantage over Mr. Romney among Michigan voters who said it mattered somewhat or a great deal that a candidate shares their religious beliefs, and those who said being a true conservative or having strong moral character mattered most in their vote.
While Mr. Santorum's recent lobbying effort to sway social conservatives to his side may have worked with evangelical Christians, it did not tempt Catholic voters - their vote divided between him and Mr. Romney. Nearly half of Catholic women voters in Michigan went for Mr. Romney, compared to less than a third for Mr. Santorum.
Voters in Michigan had concerns about Mr. Santorum's electability, hurting his opportunity of snatching the state away from Mr. Romney. Only about a quarter of Michigan primary voters said Mr. Santorum was the candidate most likely to defeat President Obama in November, and electability ranked among the most important factors for voters.
The economy was the overarching issue for Michigan voters, and nearly half of those who said the economy was their main concern were supporting Mr. Romney.
Mr. Santorum had a difficult time finding any groups to support him in large enough numbers to make a difference in his bid in Arizona, where he had little to no campaign presence and his debate performance there last week was considered lackluster.
In Arizona, Mr. Romney swept nearly all voting blocs. The former Pennsylvania senator only led Mr. Romney - and not by much - among strong Tea Party supporters, white evangelical Christians, and late-deciding voters, and tied or nearly tied with Mr. Romney among the lowest income and the most conservative voters. -Allison Kopicki
In Michigan, a More Moderate Electorate
With the first waves of exit polls in from voters in Michigan and Arizona, the state of Michigan has a slightly more moderate electorate than some previous Republican caucus and primary contests in 2012.
About 6 in 10 primary voters in Michigan consider themselves conservative, with about 3 in 10 saying they are very conservative and about the same number saying they are moderate, according to preliminary exit poll results.
One reason that Republican primary voters in Michigan may appear less conservative than other early nominating contests is that Michigan does not require voters to be registered Republicans, so anyone, including independents and Democrats, can temporarily call himself or herself a Republican and enter the voting booth.
And at least one candidate is taking advantage of that flexibility to try to improve his chances.
Mr. Romney has called Mr. Santorum's automated phone call lobbying Democrats to vote against Mr. Romney a "dirty trick." But Mr. Romney himself has admitted to voting in a Democratic primary as a registered independent, for Paul Tsongas, whom he thought would make the weakest Democratic presidential candidate in 1992. -Allison Kopicki

College Graduates and Union Members
How well will Mr. Santorum's remarks about President Obama's being a "snob" about college education go over in Michigan, and who were his targets?
Today's exit polls showed that about half of Michigan primary voters held a college degree, and about 3 in 10 had attended some college or held an associate's degree. In Florida, New Hampshire and Nevada, most college graduates supported Mr. Romney, while they were more divided in Iowa and South Carolina.
Michigan also has one of the highest union membership rates in the country. In today's primary, early exit poll results showed about one-quarter of voters said there was a union member in their household, and about one in seven said they were a union member themselves. In 2008, union households broke evenly for Mr. McCain and Mr. Romney. 
So did Democrats really come out to vote in the Republican contest more than usual today? It's hard to say: Exit poll results showed that about 1 in 10 voters in Michigan today said they usually think of themselves as a Democrat. In 2008, 7 percent of Republican primary voters identified as Democrat, and in 2000, 17 percent did.
Of the other early nominating contests with exit polls, New Hampshire, which Mr. Romney won handily, had the most moderate electorate, with just 22 percent of voters saying they were very conservative, and a slim majority saying they were conservative.
In Nevada and Iowa, more than 8 in 10 voters said they were conservative, and nearly half of all primary voters said they were very conservative. Nearly 7 in 10 voters in South Carolina and Florida considered themselves conservative. -Allison Kopicki
The Economy Wins Again
As was the case in every previous exit poll conducted in this nomination race, voters in the Arizona Republican primary overwhelmingly picked the economy as their No. 1 issue in deciding whom to support (about half of all responses). The second biggest issue cited by voters was the budget deficit (about one-third of responses). The economy was the top issue concern for supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Newt Gingrich, but supporters of Representative Ron Paul felt that the budget deficit was more important.
Also repeating the pattern found in other exit polls this season, Arizona Republican primary voters said that the most important candidate quality was the ability to beat Mr. Obama (nearly two in five responses). While this was true among supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, supporters of Mr. Paul were more likely to say that being a true conservative was the candidate quality they prized most (about one in three responses).
Half of Republican primary goers in Arizona said that a candidate sharing their religious beliefs was somewhat or greatly important to their vote. 
Just as in 2008, about one in five voters said they believed abortion should be illegal in all cases.
While 40 percent of Republican primary voters in Florida said that most illegal immigrants working in the United States should be offered a chance to apply for citizenship, in Arizona this option received the support of only one in three - about equal to the number saying they should be deported. -David R. Jones
Enthusiasm Gap in Arizona
An indicator of the lack of enthusiasm for the candidates on the ballot, half of Republican primary voters in Arizona said they strongly favored the candidate for whom they had just voted. Additionally, only about three in four said they would definitely vote for the Republican nominee in November. Among supporters of Mr. Paul, this figure was about one in three.
Only a bare majority of Arizona Republican primary voters said they had a favorable impression of Mr. McCain, the Republican nominee in the 2008 presidential election. Mr. McCain's tepid favorability suggests that his endorsement of Mr. Romney may not be influential.
Three in five Arizona Republican primary voters said that working in business better prepared a candidate to serve as president than working in government. This was also the dominant view among supporters of every candidate except for Mr. Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, whose supporters were more favorable toward government experience.
Nearly half of Arizona voters said that last week's debate was an important factor in their vote.-David R. Jones
Evangelicals and Catholics
The evangelical Christian vote has been somewhat all over the map in this year's nominating contests. Exit poll results showed Mr. Romney winning white evangelical voters in Nevada, Mr. Gingrich winning them in South Carolina, and the evangelical vote dividing between Mr. Romney and Mr. Gingrich in Florida. Earlier, in Iowa, Mr. Santorum won a plurality of white evangelicals.
(There were no exit or entrance polls in the Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota contests that Mr. Santorum swept this month.)
Intensifying his pursuit of socially conservative voters in recent days, Mr. Santorum, who is Catholic, defended the role of religion in public life this weekend, dismissing John F. Kennedy's 1960 call for the separation of religion and politics, and saying that college campuses in America are not a "neutral setting" for people of faith.
In Michigan, nearly 4 in 10 primary voters are white Christian evangelicals, according to early exit poll results, and about 3 in 10 are Catholic.
Catholic voters made up at least about one-third of voters in both New Hampshire and Florida - and in both of those states, they swung for Mr. Romney.
But only about one in seven voters in Michigan said that abortion mattered most to their vote today. Even among social conservatives, the economy was the No. 1 issue - nearly half of white evangelical voters said the economy mattered most to their decision, with nearly a quarter saying either abortion or the deficit mattered the most. -Allison Kopicki

Views on Abortion
If Mr. Santorum does manage to do better in Michigan than in Arizona, as many expect, differences on the issue of abortion could be a reason. Although anti-abortion sentiment was similar in both states (three in five voters were opposed), abortion was mentioned at least two times more often as an important issue to voters in Michigan (picked by one in seven voters) than in Arizona. And in both states, Mr. Santorum's supporters were more likely to pick this issue as important to their vote than were supporters of any of the other candidate.-David R. Jones
