HEADLINE: Huckabee Will Host a Presidential Forum on Fox News

BYLINE: JEREMY W. PETERS


HIGHLIGHT: The program is scheduled to be broadcast on Saturday, and Newt Gingrich, Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum have agreed to appear. 

 BODY:
The Republican presidential candidates may have grown tired of debating one another. But there's still one television invitation they won't turn down: Mike Huckabee's.
Mr. Huckabee will host his third presidential forum on Saturday, an executive for the Fox News Channel said on Tuesday. So far three candidates, Newt Gingrich, Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, have committed. Ron Paul has still not indicated whether he will attend. 
The program, which is scheduled from 8 to 10 p.m., will be broadcast from Ohio, the executive said, speaking anonymously because a formal announcement had not been made.
Mr. Huckabee will focus the forum on jobs and the economy, a particularly potent subject in Ohio where the manufacturing sector has suffered greatly. Underscoring that distress, the setting for the event will be a now-shuttered DHL plant in Wilmington.
Wilmington was devastated when DHL, the shipping giant, reduced its United States workforce by 9,500 three years ago. The city, with only about 12,000 residents at the time, had thousands of jobs disappear.
During the program, Mr. Huckabee will be joined by Elaine Chao, a labor secretary to George W. Bush and now a Fox News contributor, and three Ohio residents whose lives have been affected by the recession.
Mr. Huckabee, a former governor of Arkansas and Republican candidate for president in 2008, has said he would remain neutral during the primary and make no endorsement. Yet that has not stopped candidates from seeking his favor. His two other televised forums were attended by the leading Republican candidates.
Some candidates have even used Mr. Huckabee in their ads, much to his dismay. He demanded that Mr. Gingrich pull an ad that contained an old quote of his questioning Mr. Romney's honesty. Rick Perry, who withdrew from the race last month, used a picture of him standing with Mr. Huckabee in one of his commercials.
And a recent ad from Mr. Santorum featured a glowing quote praising the former Pennsylvania senator. "I adore Rick Santorum's conviction," Mr. Huckabee is quoted saying. 
Saturday also happens to be the date of another political event: the Washington state caucuses.

HEADLINE: Live Blogging Michigan and Arizona Primaries

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Times is providing live updates and analysis from the Republican primaries in Michigan and Arizona. 

 BODY:
The race for the Republican presidential nomination is not likely to be settled on Tuesday, though much is at stake for Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as voters in Michigan and Arizona head to the polls. 
The Times is covering Tuesday's contests and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.

9:13 P.M. | Anxious Romney Supporters Await Returns From Michigan
NOVI, Mich. - With 20 minutes until the polls closed in Michigan, a rumor (whispered by a Romney surrogate) whipped through the news corps: Mr. Romney was going to come out and address the crowd with a "surprise" announcement. And then, just as quickly, a new, more official verdict came down from his staff: No, there would be no early glimpse of Mr. Romney.
Instead, the guests in the ballroom, which is still filling up with a mix of nervous aides, finance types and supporters, had to settle on busying themselves with the huge projector on the left side of the room broadcasting Fox News.
When the current polls flashed across the bottom of the screen - Mr. Romney and Mr. Santorum in a dead heat with 40 percent each - the crowd offered up a scattered cheer. When Mr. Paul and Mr. Gingrich's far lower totals appeared next, they booed.
The next time the TV flashed results, Mr. Santorum had pulled into the lead - 40 percent to 38 percent. And then, a few minutes later, the screen crackled with static, and then flicked off. No word on whether the campaign didn't like the new numbers, or there were technical difficulties, but now the projector simply reads: "Romney."
However, good news was near. Moments after 9 p.m., an announcer spoke over the audio system to say that The Associated Press and CNN had called Arizona - a winner-take-all state - for Mr. Romney. A cheer went up in the room, and "Dancing in the Street" began blaring, as supporters in the bleachers didn't quite dance, but swayed slightly as they shook American flags and red-white-and-blue pom-poms.

8:59 P.M. | Paul Speaks to Supporters in Virginia
Before the races in Michigan or Arizona were called Tuesday, Mr. Paul pledged that he would continue his presidential campaign.
Speaking from Virginia, where he hopes to do well in the voting on next Tuesday, Mr. Paul said that his campaign was "still winning a lot of delegates and that's what counts."
And he said that "it is our message that appeals to the independents, to the Democrats and to the Republican base. It's the message of liberty and the message of liberty is what we were all about."
As he has in previous election-night speeches, Mr. Paul railed against the federal government, calling for the end to the income tax and the end to the Federal Reserve System.
That prompted cheers from the raucous crowd: "End the Fed! End the Fed!"
Mr. Paul's presidential campaign has focused on caucus states, where he believes his committed supporters are more likely to turn out. There are several states holding caucuses on Tuesday.
But Mr. Paul talked very little about the logistics of his campaign on Tuesday night. Instead, he used his brief platform on national television to offer his typical stump speech.
He bemoaned warmongering and called for troops to come home from wars abroad, prompting the audience to chant, "Bring them home! Bring them home."
A surprised Mr. Paul said: "You know all my lines!"
He also called for a smaller federal government that did not spend so much and did not borrow as much.

9:00 P.M. | Romney Wins Arizona; Locked in Tight Race in Michigan
Mr. Romney has won the Republican presidential primary in Arizona, based on preliminary exit polling, but is locked in a tight battle with Mr. Santorum in Michigan, a crucial electoral battleground where Mr. Romney's hometown advantage has all but evaporated.
Mr. Romney's victory in Arizona will earn him 29 delegates, extending the lead he already has over his rivals. The win comes after his rivals largely conceded that the former Massachusetts governor would win the border state.
But Michigan has been a much tougher challenge for Mr. Romney, who was raised in the state and whose father served as the state's governor. Exit polls and early returns showed Mr. Santorum mounting a fierce challenge to Mr. Romney in a state that was not expected to be close just weeks ago.
Very conservative voters and evangelical Christians appeared to be backing Mr. Santorum in large numbers, according to preliminary results of surveys of voters by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J. The surveys show Mr. Romney is getting strong support from older voters, high income voters and moderates. Mr. Romney also won voters who said defeating Mr. Obama mattered the most in making their decision.
A loss by Mr. Romney in Michigan would be a blow to a campaign that had once hoped to quickly dispatch Republican rivals so its candidate could turn his attention to Mr. Obama and the general election campaign this fall.
Mr. Santorum had pushed hard in Michigan in the last several days even as his aides said they would be happy with a narrow loss given the prior expectation that it should have been an easy state for Mr. Romney to win.
In the last 24 hours, Mr. Romney took strong exception to a final appeal by Mr. Santorum to Michigan Democrats. Mr. Santorum's campaign paid for a series of automated telephone calls to Democratic households urging a vote against Mr. Romney.
That angered Mr. Romney, who called it a "dirty trick." Mr. Santorum defended the effort, saying he was merely proving that he can reach out to moderate voters and even to Democrats.
Exit polls seemed to show that about 1 in 10 of the voters in Michigan identified themselves as Democrats. Mr. Santorum was winning about half of those voters.

8:39 P.M. | Gingrich Speaks in Georgia
Newt Gingrich the professor returned to the airwaves on Tuesday, delivering a rambling lecture - and concession speech - long before polls closed in Arizona and Michigan.
Mr. Gingrich, whose popularity has plunged in national and state polls, basically ignored both states, heading instead to his home state of Georgia, which will vote next Tuesday.
It was there, at a college where he once taught, that Mr. Gingrich offered remarks about his continuing presidential campaign.
But it was not your typical concession speech.
For more than 15 minutes, Mr. Gingrich first related several stories about his past in Georgia, including one about how he and friends tried to cut down a dying tree, only to see it crash into a house.
He then went into a lecture about energy, the subject that he has been focused on for days.
"I think this is the most important election in our lifetime," Mr. Gingrich said. "Re-electing Barack Obama will be a disaster for the country."
Gone was the fiery political combatant who railed against Mr. Romney and his Republican rivals during the South Carolina and Florida primaries earlier this year. In fact, as he talked and talked, Mr. Gingrich hardly mentioned the other Republican candidates.
In its place, Mr. Gingrich returned to his roots as a sharp-tongued critic of Mr. Obama as he assailed the president for apologizing to the Afghanistan president for the burning of the Koran.
"I think the commander in chief owes a great deal of loyalty to the people who serve the United States of America," Mr. Gingrich said. "No one in this administration is prepared to stand up for any of our values. They are very prepared to apologize to people who want to kill us."

7:58 P.M. | Automobile Politics
Mr. Romney has taken a lot of grief for saying that his wife, Ann, drives "a couple of Cadillacs."
Lucky for Mr. Romney, Cadillac owners tend to vote Republican. And even better, they go to the polls regularly. 
Car preferences are among the data points that political strategists mine for the habits of potential voters - all part of the increasingly sophisticated effort by campaigns to use statistics to gain an edge.
Campaigns analyze consumer choices, including soft drinks and beer, television shows and magazine subscriptions. With this data, they can identify consumers' likely party affiliations and even how often they vote.
When it comes to cars, the results are often predictable. It probably won't surprise anyone to learn that the data, as collected by Scarborough Research, show that drivers of hybrid automobiles nationwide tend to skew Democrat and are highly likely to vote. The same goes for Subaru owners. Saab and Volvo owners also lean left and vote in large percentages, though not by as wide a margin.
Toyota and Honda drivers skew slightly to the left and are modestly more likely to show up at the ballot box. 
Jaguar, on the other hand, has the highest concentration of high-turnout Republicans. That brand is followed by Lincoln, Buick, Lexus and Cadillac. Mercedes-Benz drivers also tend to be Republican and vote at higher than average rates.
Ford is a Republican-leaning brand, but its voter participation rates are close to average. The same is true for Chevrolet, Jeep and Porsche.
In Michigan, the heart of the domestic auto industry, those patterns largely hold, but with some surprising variations.
The most Republican brand and the one with the highest voter turnout is Hummer. Volvo, which is often stereotyped as the car brand of choice for college professors and other well-off liberal professionals, skews Republican in Michigan.

7:34 P.M. | In Michigan, Romney Criticizes Santorum Democrats
LIVONIA, Mich. - Michigan - the state where Mr. Romney grew up as the son of an auto executive turned governor, and the state where he thinks the trees are still just "the right height" - turned into an unexpectedly close race between Mr. Romney and Mr. Santorum. When Mr. Romney heads to his election night party Tuesday evening, it remains to be seen just how much of a "party" it will be.
Though it is entirely possible that Mr. Romney could win Michigan and Arizona tonight, helping tamp down the threat from Mr. Santorum and regaining some momentum of his own, Mr. Romney sought to lower expectations during a news conference Tuesday morning at his Michigan headquarters.
As late as Monday, Mr. Romney had been showing signs of confidence here, going so far as to predict a Michigan win. But on the day that voters headed to the polls, he struck a slightly softer note.
While Arizona is a winner-takes-all state, Michigan awards its delegates proportionally, and Mr. Romney made a show of focusing on the delegates rather than winning the entire state.
"What we are after is delegates, so make sure we cover all the Congressional districts where we think we have the best shot of picking up delegates," he said. "This is a race to get the delegates I need to become our nominee. We've got delegates here in Michigan, of course, district by district."
Mr. Romney added that, in Michigan, "We have got to make sure that each one of those 14 districts we get as many of them as possible and get the delegates I need."
Mr. Romney also began his remarks by referring to a flap that erupted Monday night, when Mr. Santorum's campaign admitted to calling Democratic voters to urge them to head to the polls to vote against Mr. Romney.
Later, when asked why Michigan seemed to be proving a more difficult state for him to win than expected, Mr. Romney again returned to the Santorum "robocalls."
"I think the hardest thing about predicting what's going to happen today is whether Senator Santorum's effort to call Democrat households and tell them to come out and vote against Mitt Romney is going to be successful or not," he said.
Later, in the lobby of the hotel where Mr. Romney and his staff are staying, aides sought to play up Mr. Santorum's Democrats-to-the-polls strategy, making a point of chatting with reporters about the tactic.
Though Mr. Romney stepped up Tuesday to take some of the blame for his struggling campaign, if he loses tonight, expect him and his team to lay as much of the results as possible at the feet of Mr. Santorum - and his pesky Democrats.
- 
7:35 P.M. | Voter Portraits: Detroit
Name: Alia Allen
Location: Detroit
Age: 34
Political affiliation: Democrat
Occupation: Academic adviser
Most important issue: Campaign finance
Preferred candidate: Barack Obama but voted for Rick Santorum
- 
7:18 P.M. | Where's Newt?
Mr. Gingrich is sitting out the Arizona and Michigan primaries. He decided not to aggressively contest Arizona, and he has skipped Michigan altogether, hoping that Mr. Santorum's strength there will do serious damage to Mr. Romney. 
Instead, Mr. Gingrich is putting all his hopes for a comeback into a Southern strategy that calls for him to do well next week on Super Tuesday by winning Georgia, his former home, and finishing credibly in Tennessee and Oklahoma. It is a long-shot strategy, but Mr. Gingrich has been counted out at least twice before in this campaign and has bounded into the lead. If Mr. Santorum performs poorly in Michigan, Mr. Gingrich will be able to renew his claim to be the conservative alternative to Mr. Romney. And he is likely to be helped by a new $1.7 million television advertising campaign from his "super PAC" in the South, including in Mississippi and Alabama, which vote on March 13.
"I think for sure we're going to carry Georgia," Mr. Gingrich said Tuesday morning on NBC's "Today" show. 
Still, he was playing an unusual degree of defense in his must-win state. He began a three-day bus tour of Georgia on Tuesday. 
In recent days, he has boiled down his message to almost a single populist issue - a promise to get gas prices to $2.50 a gallon. But given Mr. Gingrich's restless mind, it is unlikely to remain the only issue for long.

7:07 P.M. | Exit Polls: Views on Abortion
If Mr. Santorum does manage to do better in Michigan than in Arizona, as many expect, differences on the issue of abortion could be a reason. Although anti-abortion sentiment was similar in both states (three in five voters were opposed), abortion was mentioned at least two times more often as an important issue to voters in Michigan (picked by one in seven voters) than in Arizona. And in both states, Mr. Santorum's supporters were more likely to pick this issue as important to their vote than were supporters of any of the other candidate.

Preferred candidate: Representative Ron Paul

6:57 P.M. | Exit Polls: Evangelicals and Catholics
The evangelical Christian vote has been somewhat all over the map in this year's nominating contests. Exit poll results showed Mr. Romney winning white evangelical voters in Nevada, Mr. Gingrich winning them in South Carolina, and the evangelical vote dividing between Mr. Romney and Mr. Gingrich in Florida. Earlier, in Iowa, Mr. Santorum won a plurality of white evangelicals.
(There were no exit or entrance polls in the Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota contests that Mr. Santorum swept this month.) 
Intensifying his pursuit of socially conservative voters in recent days, Mr. Santorum, who is Catholic, defended the role of religion in public life this weekend, dismissing John F. Kennedy's 1960 speech on the separation of religion and politics, and saying that college campuses in America are not a "neutral setting" for people of faith.
In Michigan, nearly 4 in 10 primary voters are white Christian evangelicals, according to early exit poll results, and about 3 in 10 are Catholic.
Catholic voters made up at least about one-third of voters in both New Hampshire and Florida - and in both of those states, they swung for Mr. Romney.
But only about one in seven voters in Michigan said that abortion mattered most to their vote today. Even among social conservatives, the economy was the No. 1 issue - nearly half of white evangelical voters said the economy mattered most to their decision, with nearly a quarter saying either abortion or the deficit mattered the most.
- 
6:46 P.M. | Caucus Click: A Diverse Electorate in Michigan
- 
6:32 P.M. | Romney Looks to Win Conservative Voters
When Mr. Romney won Nevada's caucus on the heels of another victory in Florida, his campaign argued that he had finally made inroads with voters who call themselves very conservative.
In fact, in Nevada, Mr. Romney finally won that category, capturing 46 percent of the "very conservative" vote, while Mr. Gingrich only took 25 percent and Mr. Santorum (who did not campaign much there) took 15 percent.
But was that a fluke? Many of those who said they were very conservative also were Mormons, a group much more inclined to vote for Mr. Romney, who is a Mormon.
And a few days later, Mr. Romney got walloped in Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota. Exit and entrance polling was not available, but Mr. Santorum's campaign claimed credit for scoring big among the most conservative voters in those states.
Now, watching how those voters cast their ballots in Michigan and Arizona will be very interesting.
In Michigan, Mr. Santorum should have an edge. He has been talking at length about social issues, speaking in the kind of language that helps to fire up the Tea Party and evangelical bases of the Republican Party.
Arizona might be a bit different. The candidates have spent less time there, and immigration is a bigger deal in the border state. How does that cut for very conservative voters? That's unclear. Mr. Romney has tacked sharply to the right on the issue of illegal immigration, but Mr. Santorum is no liberal on the issue either.
The results of the "very conservative" block are probably of greater importance for Mr. Romney, who still faces questions about his ability to excite that kind of voter. If he improves tonight, that will help his campaign going forward.
- 
6:29 P.M. | Voter Portraits: Phoenix 
Name: Rand Vogel
Location: Phoenix
Age: 57
Political affiliation: Republican
Occupation: General contractor
Most important issue: Economy
Preferred candidate: Rick Santorum
- 
6:22 P.M. | Exit Polls: Enthusiasm Gap in Arizona
An indicator of the lack of enthusiasm for the candidates on the ballot, half of Republican primary voters in Arizona said they strongly favored the candidate for whom they had just voted. Additionally, only about three in four said they would definitely vote for the Republican nominee in November. Among supporters of Mr. Paul, this figure was about one in three.
Only a bare majority of Arizona Republican primary voters said they had a favorable impression of Mr. McCain, the Republican nominee in the 2008 presidential election. Mr. McCain's tepid favorability suggests that his endorsement of Mr. Romney may not be influential. 
Three in five Arizona Republican primary voters said that working in business better prepared a candidate to serve as president than working in government. This was also the dominant view among supporters of every candidate except for Mr. Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, whose supporters were more favorable toward government experience.
Nearly half of Arizona voters said that last week's debate was an important factor in their vote.
- 
6:09 P.M. | Exit Polls: The Economy Wins Again
As was the case in every previous exit poll conducted in this nomination race, voters in the Arizona Republican primary overwhelmingly picked the economy as their No. 1 issue in deciding whom to support (about half of all responses). The second biggest issue cited by voters was the budget deficit (about one-third of responses). The economy was the top issue concern for supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, but supporters of Ron Paul felt that the budget deficit was more important.
Also repeating the pattern found in other exit polls this season, Arizona Republican primary voters said that the most important candidate quality was the ability to beat Mr. Obama (nearly two in five responses). While this was true among supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, supporters of Mr. Paul were more likely to say that being a true conservative was the candidate quality they prized most (about one in three responses). 
Half of Republican primary goers in Arizona said that a candidate sharing their religious beliefs was somewhat or greatly important to their vote. 
Just as in 2008, about one in five voters said they believed abortion should be illegal in all cases.
While 40 percent of Republican primary voters in Florida said that most illegal immigrants working in the United States should be offered a chance to apply for citizenship, in Arizona this option received the support of only one in three - about equal to the number saying they should be deported. 
- 
6:01 P.M. | Santorum and Female Voters
Has Mr. Santorum angered women?
For the past week, Mr. Santorum has been taking positions that might turn off some women, especially independents from the suburbs. He focused on contraception for days and over the weekend called Mr. Obama a "snob" for advocating on behalf of college.
Those are subjects that may fire up Mr. Santorum's base, but they threaten to depress his vote among women, particularly in the parts of Michigan that are more moderate.
So the question will be whether women will decide they would rather support Mr. Romney, and whether that support will be enough to help overcome Mr. Romney's other weaknesses.
If that gender gap between the two candidates begins to widen as the night progresses, Mr. Santorum could find himself on the losing side tonight.
- 
5:58 P.M. | Exit Polls: College Graduates and Union Members
How well will Mr. Santorum's remarks about President Obama's being a "snob" about college education go over in Michigan, and who were his targets? 
Today's exit polls showed that about half of Michigan primary voters held a college degree, and about 3 in 10 had attended some college or held an associate's degree. In Florida, New Hampshire and Nevada, most college graduates supported Mr. Romney, while they were more divided in Iowa and South Carolina.
Michigan also has one of the highest union membership rates in the country. In today's primary, early exit poll results showed about one-quarter of voters said there was a union member in their household, and about one in seven said they were a union member themselves. In 2008, union households broke evenly for Mr. McCain and Mr. Romney.
- 
5:53 P.M. | Exit Polls: In Michigan, a More Moderate Electorate
With the first waves of exit polls in from voters in Michigan and Arizona, the state of Michigan has a slightly more moderate electorate than some previous Republican caucus and primary contests in 2012.
About 6 in 10 primary voters in Michigan consider themselves conservative, with about 3 in 10 saying they are very conservative and about the same number saying they are moderate, according to preliminary exit poll results.
One reason that Republican primary voters in Michigan may appear less conservative than other early nominating contests is that Michigan does not require voters to be registered Republicans, so anyone, including independents and Democrats, can temporarily call himself or herself a Republican and enter the voting booth.
And at least one candidate is taking advantage of that flexibility to try to improve his chances.
Mr. Romney has called Mr. Santorum's automated phone call lobbying Democrats to vote against Mr. Romney a "dirty trick." But Mr. Romney himself has admitted to voting in a Democratic primary as a registered independent, for Paul Tsongas, whom he thought would make the weakest Democratic presidential candidate in 1992.
So did Democrats really come out to vote in the Republican contest more than usual today? It's hard to say: Exit poll results showed that about 1 in 10 voters in Michigan today said they usually think of themselves as a Democrat. In 2008, 7 percent of Republican primary voters identified as Democrat, and in 2000, 17 percent did.
Of the other early nominating contests with exit polls, New Hampshire, which Mr. Romney won handily, had the most moderate electorate, with just 22 percent of voters saying they were very conservative, and a slim majority saying they were conservative.
In Nevada and Iowa, more than 8 in 10 voters said they were conservative, and nearly half of all primary voters said they were very conservative. Nearly 7 in 10 voters in South Carolina and Florida considered themselves conservative.
- 
5:26 P.M. | Video: Primary Day
- 
5:30 P.M. | Arizona Looks Like Less of a Nail-Biter
There are 29 delegates at stake in Arizona, and the Republicans gathered there last week for what was being billed as the last debate of the Republican contest. But in the end, the contest there is ending up as something of an afterthought, overshadowed by the fight going on in Michigan on Tuesday. The candidates have barely been in the state since the debate.
One reason? Polls suggest that this will be an easy win for Mr. Romney, the former Massachusetts governor. For what it's worth, he received the endorsement of Jan Brewer, the Republican governor of Arizona, last week, and has the backing of Senator John McCain. And the state has a sizable population of Mormons - Mr. Romney is a Mormon - who turned out at the campaign rallies he held during his last visit to the state last week.
Unlike Michigan, this is a closed primary, meaning that only registered Republicans are permitted to vote. Polls close at 9 p.m. Eastern time. In 2008, the primary was won by Mr. McCain in what was also something less than a nail-biter.
- 
5:28 P.M. | Could Early Voters Turn Michigan?
As the Michigan votes start rolling in tonight, keep an eye on the votes that were cast before today.
Early voting rewards campaigns that are highly organized, like Mr. Romney's. They can identify voters that might support a candidate, make sure they get an early ballot, and follow up to make sure voters fill out and returns their ballot.
The expectation is that Mr. Romney's campaign has done well in early voting in Michigan. That could give him an early lead as the voting gets under way. But that lead could evaporate if Mr. Santorum's election-day voters turn out in much larger numbers.
Early voting has already made a difference in the 2012 campaign. Mr. Romney's campaign methodically pushed his supporters in Florida to vote early, helping him defeat Newt Gingrich during the primary there at the end of last month.
Will it make the same difference in Michigan? We should know soon enough.
- 
5:13 P.M. | Setting the Stage in Michigan and Arizona
The intensity of the rhetorical battle between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum before the primaries in Michigan and Arizona would suggest that a denouement might finally be at hand.
But it's possible that little will be settled Tuesday night.
In part, that's because the race in Michigan appears to be very close; a matter of just a few thousand votes could separate the victor from his nearest competitor. Winning by a hair will hardly confer unstoppable momentum.
There's also the delegate count. Almost all of Michigan's delegates are awarded at the district level: two delegates for the winner of each Congressional district. The rules raise the real possibility that the winner of the popular vote could be on the losing end of the delegate tally.
And finally, there's Arizona. A decisive win there for Mr. Romney - who is far ahead in the state polls, even as he struggles in Michigan - would muddle the political picture from the two contests even further.

PUB-DATE: February 28, 2012

HEADLINE: Live Blogging Michigan and Arizona Primaries

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Times is providing live updates and analysis from the Republican primaries in Michigan and Arizona. 

 BODY:
The race for the Republican presidential nomination is not likely to be settled on Tuesday, though much is at stake for Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as voters in Michigan and Arizona head to the polls. 
The Times is covering Tuesday's contests and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.
Live Dashboard Download the Election 2012 App: iPhone | AndroidTwitter: @thecaucus | The Times Political Unit | @fivethirtyeightResults: Michigan | Arizona
10:55 P.M. | Breaking Down Romney's Support
Mr. Romney's big victory in Arizona and his strong showing in Michigan were both largely fueled by the same coalition of voters that have consistently expressed their support for Mr. Romney in exit polls throughout the primary season. In particular, Mr. Romney once again did best among older voters, better educated voters and higher income voters.
In terms of issues, Mr. Romney won in both states by large margins among voters who felt that the economy was the most important issue and among those who felt the budget deficit was the most important issue.
Voters who were looking primarily for a candidate who can beat President Obama also gravitated to Mr. Romney, as did those who said experience was the most important candidate quality.
Mr. Romney, who has had to answer questions about his positions on abortion, also did much better than his opponents among voters who would approve of abortion being legal in most or all cases.
In recent weeks, Mr. Romney has been less of a heavy favorite than he had been before the voting started in January, but he continues to do best among voters who say they made up their minds before January.
Arizona Mormons Provide an Edge

Mr. Romney polled slightly better overall in Arizona than in Michigan, but the exit polls reveal that an important source of his advantage in Arizona may have been the state's Mormon population.
Among almost every group, Romney actually polled about the same in Arizona as he did in Michigan. However, his performance was surprisingly strong in a few areas. One clear advantage was among the state's Mormon population. Mormons made up nearly one out of every seven voters in Arizona's primary. Mr. Romney carried 9 in 10 of these Mormon votes.
But this advantage among Mormons also appeared to produce some other unusual voting patterns. For example, while Mr. Paul had been consistently winning younger voters, in Arizona Mr. Romney won twice as many votes among those 18 to 29. This reason becomes more clear when one considers that Mormon voters are considerably younger than the typical Arizona voter. While only 1 in 10 Arizona voters overall were between 18 to 29, among Mormons nearly 4 in 10 fell into this age category.
Similarly, while in other states Mr. Romney had generally been losing among voters who said abortion should be illegal in all cases, in Arizona he drew almost as much support as Mr. Santorum (about 2 in 5 of these voters). However, if Mormon voters are excluded, Mr. Romney only wins half as many anti-abortion votes as Mr. Santorum.
- 
10:43 P.M. | Romney Declares Victory, With a Sense of Relief
There was a palpable sense of relief on the faces of Mr. Romney's aides as Michigan was called for their candidate - by four or five points - and they emerged from their backstage holding area. Senior advisers high-fived one another and hugged, and made little effort to hide the profound relief they felt over averting an embarrassing defeat. At least one Michigan staff member had tears in her eyes.
When Mr. Romney took the stage, at first accompanied by his wife, Ann, and his oldest son, Tagg, Mrs. Romney made a point of giving shout-outs to a long list of Michigan surrogates - including Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, Donald Trump and Kid Rock, who played a mini-show (a lone number - the Romney campaign's theme song, "Born Free") Monday night.
And Mr. Romney, before beginning his victory night speech that attacked Mr. Obama, also acknowledged what a squeaker the race had become.
"We didn't win by a lot, but we won by enough, and that's all that counts," Mr. Romney said, thanking the volunteers who had knocked on doors and made phone calls for his campaign.
- 
10:39 P.M. | Santorum Addresses Supporters and Pivots to Ohio
Mr. Santorum declared himself thankful for placing second in Michigan's primary on Tuesday, saying that he "came into the backyard of one of my opponents" and did well where no one had expected him to.
Mr. Santorum talked for about 20 minutes without directly acknowledging that he had failed to win the Michigan primary and barely mentioned the name of Mr. Romney, his chief rival.
Instead, he quickly sought to return to the message of small government and help for manufacturing that had dominated his campaign before he began talking about social issues in the past week.
"It's getting harder for people to make ends meet because we have a government that is crushing us every single day," Mr. Santorum said.
He pledged an energy policy that expands oil drilling and criticized Mr. Obama as a leader who always says "no" to the efforts of Americans to produce energy.
"We need a president who says 'yes' to the American people on energy production," Mr. Santorum said.
With an eye on the Ohio primary coming up in a week, Mr. Santorum renewed his pledge to take the corporate tax on manufacturing to zero - an issue that could play well in the Rust Belt state.
He also vowed to repeal Mr. Obama's health care plan. It was then that he mentioned Mr. Romney by name, saying that Republicans needed a candidate who would provide a contrast with the president.
"Not Romneycare or Obamacare," he said, but "you care, because that's what we believe in in America."
- 
10:34 P.M. | Santorum Was Strong With Conservatives in Michigan
Leading up to today's primaries, Mr. Santorum campaigned heavily in Michigan, but spent little time or money in Arizona, and that bet showed at the polls.
According to exit poll results, Mr. Santorum found strength among a number of important groups in Michigan to rival Mr. Romney in his home state: union households, strong supporters of the Tea Party, white evangelical Christians and those who consider themselves very conservative.
He also held a strong advantage over Mr. Romney among Michigan voters who said it mattered somewhat or a great deal that a candidate share their religious beliefs, and those who said being a true conservative or having strong moral character mattered most in their vote.
While Mr. Santorum's recent lobbying effort to sway social conservatives to his side may have worked with evangelical Christians, it did not lure Catholic voters - their vote was divided between him and Mr. Romney. Nearly half of Catholic female voters in Michigan went for Mr. Romney, compared with less than a third for Mr. Santorum.
Voters in Michigan had concerns about Mr. Santorum's electability, hurting his opportunity of snatching the state away from Mr. Romney. Only about a quarter of Michigan primary voters said Mr. Santorum was the candidate most likely to defeat Mr. Obama in November, and electability ranked among the most important factors for voters.
The economy was the overarching issue for Michigan voters, and nearly half of those who said the economy was their main concern were supporting Mr. Romney.
Mr. Santorum had a difficult time finding any groups to support him in large enough numbers to make a difference in his bid in Arizona, where he had little to no campaign presence and where his debate performance last week was considered lackluster.
In Arizona, Mr. Romney swept nearly all voting blocs. Mr. Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator, only led Mr. Romney - and not by much - among strong Tea Party supporters, white evangelical Christians, and late-deciding voters, and was tied or nearly tied with Mr. Romney among the lowest income and the most conservative voters.
- 
10:14 P.M. | Romney Wins Close Primary in Michigan
Mitt Romney has narrowly won the Republican presidential primary in Michigan, deflecting a powerful challenge from Rick Santorum and bolstering his hopes of becoming the Republican nominee.
Only weeks ago, Mr. Romney had viewed his home state of Michigan as a firewall against his rivals, an important battleground state where his background and his message would carry the day.
That changed dramatically in the wake of victories by Mr. Santorum in Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota this month. Within days, Mr. Santorum surged to a double-digit lead in Michigan.
In the past two weeks, Mr. Romney battled back, aided by millions of dollars in negative campaign ads broadcast by the "super PAC" backing his campaign, and a stepped-up attack on Mr. Santorum's record.
Mr. Santorum also stumbled in a debate last week, giving Mr. Romney several opportunities to hammer his claims to being the most principled, conservative candidate. In particular, Mr. Romney seized on Mr. Santorum's admission that he voted in Congress against his principles at times.
For Mr. Romney, the victory helps mitigate what might have become a crisis for his White House bid as the campaign heads into the biggest single day of voting in one week. Voters in 10 states will cast ballots on Super Tuesday a week from now.
But the difficulty that Mr. Romney had in Michigan served to once again highlight his weakness with the base of the Republican Party. And it raised new questions about whether he could compete effectively across the Rust Belt in the general election this fall.
Mr. Santorum has already said he planned to campaign hard in Ohio, a critical state that will hold its primary next Tuesday. The race there may quickly become the next major battlefield for the two candidates. Mr. Santorum has claimed an advantage in the state, which is geographically and demographically similar to his own home state of
Pennsylvania.
Mr. Romney may also struggle in several other states. Newt Gingrich is already campaigning in Georgia, Tennessee and Oklahoma: states where Mr. Romney is not expected to do well.
For Mr. Santorum, the loss in Michigan will slow the momentum he gained from the earlier victories in February. But aides said they expected that Mr. Santorum's fund-raising could still accelerate because he was so competitive in the state.
Very conservative voters and evangelical Christians backed Mr. Santorum in larger numbers than they did Mr. Romney, according to surveys of voters by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J. But the surveys showed that Mr. Romney was getting strong support from older voters, high income voters and moderates. Mr. Romney also won voters who said defeating Mr. Obama mattered the most in making their decision.
Mr. Santorum appeared to also get a bump from Democrats, though not as much as some had predicted. Exit poll surveys suggested that about 9 percent of those who voted identified themselves as Democrats.
Mr. Santorum also benefited from his appeals to conservative voters for the past week. He criticized contraception, said that President John F. Kennedy's comments about a church-state separation made him "throw up," and he called Mr. Obama a "snob" for advocating college.

9:13 P.M. | Anxious Romney Supporters Await Returns From Michigan
NOVI, Mich. - With 20 minutes until the polls closed in Michigan, a rumor (whispered by a Romney surrogate) whipped through the news corps: Mr. Romney was going to come out and address the crowd with a "surprise" announcement. And then, just as quickly, a new, more official verdict came down from his staff: No, there would be no early glimpse of Mr. Romney.
Instead, the guests in the ballroom, which is still filling up with a mix of nervous aides, finance types and supporters, had to settle on busying themselves with the huge projector on the left side of the room broadcasting Fox News.
When the current polls flashed across the bottom of the screen - Mr. Romney and Mr. Santorum in a dead heat with 40 percent each - the crowd offered up a scattered cheer. When Mr. Paul and Mr. Gingrich's far lower totals appeared next, they booed.
The next time the TV flashed results, Mr. Santorum had pulled into the lead - 40 percent to 38 percent. And then, a few minutes later, the screen crackled with static, and then flicked off. No word on whether the campaign didn't like the new numbers, or there were technical difficulties, but now the projector simply reads: "Romney."
However, good news was near. Moments after 9 p.m., an announcer spoke over the audio system to say that The Associated Press and CNN had called Arizona - a winner-take-all state - for Mr. Romney. A cheer went up in the room, and "Dancing in the Street" began blaring, as supporters in the bleachers didn't quite dance, but swayed slightly as they shook American flags and red-white-and-blue pom-poms.
- 
8:59 P.M. | Paul Speaks to Supporters in Virginia
Before the races in Michigan or Arizona were called Tuesday, Mr. Paul pledged that he would continue his presidential campaign.
Speaking from Virginia, where he hopes to do well in the voting on next Tuesday, Mr. Paul said that his campaign was "still winning a lot of delegates and that's what counts."
And he said that "it is our message that appeals to the independents, to the Democrats and to the Republican base. It's the message of liberty and the message of liberty is what we were all about."
As he has in previous election-night speeches, Mr. Paul railed against the federal government, calling for the end to the income tax and the end to the Federal Reserve System.
That prompted cheers from the raucous crowd: "End the Fed! End the Fed!"
Mr. Paul's presidential campaign has focused on caucus states, where he believes his committed supporters are more likely to turn out. There are several states holding caucuses on Tuesday.
But Mr. Paul talked very little about the logistics of his campaign on Tuesday night. Instead, he used his brief platform on national television to offer his typical stump speech.
He bemoaned warmongering and called for troops to come home from wars abroad, prompting the audience to chant, "Bring them home! Bring them home."
A surprised Mr. Paul said: "You know all my lines!"
He also called for a smaller federal government that did not spend so much and did not borrow as much.
- 
9:00 P.M. | Romney Wins Arizona; Locked in Tight Race in Michigan
Mr. Romney has won the Republican presidential primary in Arizona, based on preliminary exit polling, but is locked in a tight battle with Mr. Santorum in Michigan, a crucial electoral battleground where Mr. Romney's hometown advantage has all but evaporated.
Mr. Romney's victory in Arizona will earn him 29 delegates, extending the lead he already has over his rivals. The win comes after his rivals largely conceded that the former Massachusetts governor would win the border state.
But Michigan has been a much tougher challenge for Mr. Romney, who was raised in the state and whose father served as the state's governor. Exit polls and early returns showed Mr. Santorum mounting a fierce challenge to Mr. Romney in a state that was not expected to be close just weeks ago.
Very conservative voters and evangelical Christians appeared to be backing Mr. Santorum in large numbers, according to preliminary results of surveys of voters by Edison Research of Somerville, N.J. The surveys show Mr. Romney is getting strong support from older voters, high income voters and moderates. Mr. Romney also won voters who said defeating Mr. Obama mattered the most in making their decision.
A loss by Mr. Romney in Michigan would be a blow to a campaign that had once hoped to quickly dispatch Republican rivals so its candidate could turn his attention to Mr. Obama and the general election campaign this fall.
Mr. Santorum had pushed hard in Michigan in the last several days even as his aides said they would be happy with a narrow loss given the prior expectation that it should have been an easy state for Mr. Romney to win.
In the last 24 hours, Mr. Romney took strong exception to a final appeal by Mr. Santorum to Michigan Democrats. Mr. Santorum's campaign paid for a series of automated telephone calls to Democratic households urging a vote against Mr. Romney.
That angered Mr. Romney, who called it a "dirty trick." Mr. Santorum defended the effort, saying he was merely proving that he can reach out to moderate voters and even to Democrats.
Exit polls seemed to show that about 1 in 10 of the voters in Michigan identified themselves as Democrats. Mr. Santorum was winning about half of those voters.
- 
8:58 P.M. | Voter Portraits: Glendale, Ariz.

Most important issue: Economy

8:39 P.M. | Gingrich Speaks in Georgia
Newt Gingrich the professor returned to the airwaves on Tuesday, delivering a rambling lecture - and concession speech - long before polls closed in Arizona and Michigan.
Mr. Gingrich, whose popularity has plunged in national and state polls, basically ignored both states, heading instead to his home state of Georgia, which will vote next Tuesday.
It was there, at a college where he once taught, that Mr. Gingrich offered remarks about his continuing presidential campaign.
But it was not your typical concession speech.
For more than 15 minutes, Mr. Gingrich first related several stories about his past in Georgia, including one about how he and friends tried to cut down a dying tree, only to see it crash into a house.
He then went into a lecture about energy, the subject that he has been focused on for days.
"I think this is the most important election in our lifetime," Mr. Gingrich said. "Re-electing Barack Obama will be a disaster for the country."
Gone was the fiery political combatant who railed against Mr. Romney and his Republican rivals during the South Carolina and Florida primaries earlier this year. In fact, as he talked and talked, Mr. Gingrich hardly mentioned the other Republican candidates.
In its place, Mr. Gingrich returned to his roots as a sharp-tongued critic of Mr. Obama as he assailed the president for apologizing to the Afghanistan president for the burning of the Koran.
"I think the commander in chief owes a great deal of loyalty to the people who serve the United States of America," Mr. Gingrich said. "No one in this administration is prepared to stand up for any of our values. They are very prepared to apologize to people who want to kill us."
-

8:05 P.M. | Caucus Click: Preparing Paul's Primary Party

7:58 P.M. | Automobile Politics
Mr. Romney has taken a lot of grief for saying that his wife, Ann, drives "a couple of Cadillacs."
Lucky for Mr. Romney, Cadillac owners tend to vote Republican. And even better, they go to the polls regularly. 
Car preferences are among the data points that political strategists mine for the habits of potential voters - all part of the increasingly sophisticated effort by campaigns to use statistics to gain an edge.
Campaigns analyze consumer choices, including soft drinks and beer, television shows and magazine subscriptions. With this data, they can identify consumers' likely party affiliations and even how often they vote.
When it comes to cars, the results are often predictable. It probably won't surprise anyone to learn that the data, as collected by Scarborough Research, show that drivers of hybrid automobiles nationwide tend to skew Democrat and are highly likely to vote. The same goes for Subaru owners. Saab and Volvo owners also lean left and vote in large percentages, though not by as wide a margin.
Toyota and Honda drivers skew slightly to the left and are modestly more likely to show up at the ballot box. 
Jaguar, on the other hand, has the highest concentration of high-turnout Republicans. That brand is followed by Lincoln, Buick, Lexus and Cadillac. Mercedes-Benz drivers also tend to be Republican and vote at higher than average rates.
Ford is a Republican-leaning brand, but its voter participation rates are close to average. The same is true for Chevrolet, Jeep and Porsche.
In Michigan, the heart of the domestic auto industry, those patterns largely hold, but with some surprising variations.
The most Republican brand and the one with the highest voter turnout is Hummer. Volvo, which is often stereotyped as the car brand of choice for college professors and other well-off liberal professionals, skews Republican in Michigan. 
- 
7:53 P.M. | Voter Portraits: Phoenix

Age: 65
Political affiliation: Republican
Occupation: Retired
Most important issue: Economy and defense
Preferred candidate: Newt Gingrich

7:34 P.M. | In Michigan, Romney Criticizes Santorum Democrats
LIVONIA, Mich. - Michigan - the state where Mr. Romney grew up as the son of an auto executive turned governor, and the state where he thinks the trees are still just "the right height" - turned into an unexpectedly close race between Mr. Romney and Mr. Santorum. When Mr. Romney heads to his election night party Tuesday evening, it remains to be seen just how much of a "party" it will be.
Though it is entirely possible that Mr. Romney could win Michigan and Arizona tonight, helping tamp down the threat from Mr. Santorum and regaining some momentum of his own, Mr. Romney sought to lower expectations during a news conference Tuesday morning at his Michigan headquarters.
As late as Monday, Mr. Romney had been showing signs of confidence here, going so far as to predict a Michigan win. But on the day that voters headed to the polls, he struck a slightly softer note.
While Arizona is a winner-takes-all state, Michigan awards its delegates proportionally, and Mr. Romney made a show of focusing on the delegates rather than winning the entire state.
"What we are after is delegates, so make sure we cover all the Congressional districts where we think we have the best shot of picking up delegates," he said. "This is a race to get the delegates I need to become our nominee. We've got delegates here in Michigan, of course, district by district."
Mr. Romney added that, in Michigan, "We have got to make sure that each one of those 14 districts we get as many of them as possible and get the delegates I need."
Mr. Romney also began his remarks by referring to a flap that erupted Monday night, when Mr. Santorum's campaign admitted to calling Democratic voters to urge them to head to the polls to vote against Mr. Romney.
Later, when asked why Michigan seemed to be proving a more difficult state for him to win than expected, Mr. Romney again returned to the Santorum "robocalls."
"I think the hardest thing about predicting what's going to happen today is whether Senator Santorum's effort to call Democrat households and tell them to come out and vote against Mitt Romney is going to be successful or not," he said.
Later, in the lobby of the hotel where Mr. Romney and his staff are staying, aides sought to play up Mr. Santorum's Democrats-to-the-polls strategy, making a point of chatting with reporters about the tactic.
Though Mr. Romney stepped up Tuesday to take some of the blame for his struggling campaign, if he loses tonight, expect him and his team to lay as much of the results as possible at the feet of Mr. Santorum - and his pesky Democrats.

7:35 P.M. | Voter Portraits: Detroit

7:18 P.M. | Where's Newt?
Mr. Gingrich is sitting out the Arizona and Michigan primaries. He decided not to aggressively contest Arizona, and he has skipped Michigan altogether, hoping that Mr. Santorum's strength there will do serious damage to Mr. Romney. 
Instead, Mr. Gingrich is putting all his hopes for a comeback into a Southern strategy that calls for him to do well next week on Super Tuesday by winning Georgia, his former home, and finishing credibly in Tennessee and Oklahoma. It is a long-shot strategy, but Mr. Gingrich has been counted out at least twice before in this campaign and has bounded into the lead. If Mr. Santorum performs poorly in Michigan, Mr. Gingrich will be able to renew his claim to be the conservative alternative to Mr. Romney. And he is likely to be helped by a new $1.7 million television advertising campaign from his "super PAC" in the South, including in Mississippi and Alabama, which vote on March 13.
"I think for sure we're going to carry Georgia," Mr. Gingrich said Tuesday morning on NBC's "Today" show. 
Still, he was playing an unusual degree of defense in his must-win state. He began a three-day bus tour of Georgia on Tuesday. 
In recent days, he has boiled down his message to almost a single populist issue - a promise to get gas prices to $2.50 a gallon. But given Mr. Gingrich's restless mind, it is unlikely to remain the only issue for long.

7:07 P.M. | Exit Polls: Views on Abortion
If Mr. Santorum does manage to do better in Michigan than in Arizona, as many expect, differences on the issue of abortion could be a reason. Although anti-abortion sentiment was similar in both states (three in five voters were opposed), abortion was mentioned at least two times more often as an important issue to voters in Michigan (picked by one in seven voters) than in Arizona. And in both states, Mr. Santorum's supporters were more likely to pick this issue as important to their vote than were supporters of any of the other candidate.

6:57 P.M. | Exit Polls: Evangelicals and Catholics
The evangelical Christian vote has been somewhat all over the map in this year's nominating contests. Exit poll results showed Mr. Romney winning white evangelical voters in Nevada, Mr. Gingrich winning them in South Carolina, and the evangelical vote dividing between Mr. Romney and Mr. Gingrich in Florida. Earlier, in Iowa, Mr. Santorum won a plurality of white evangelicals.
(There were no exit or entrance polls in the Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota contests that Mr. Santorum swept this month.) 
Intensifying his pursuit of socially conservative voters in recent days, Mr. Santorum, who is Catholic, defended the role of religion in public life this weekend, dismissing John F. Kennedy's 1960 speech on the separation of religion and politics, and saying that college campuses in America are not a "neutral setting" for people of faith.
In Michigan, nearly 4 in 10 primary voters are white Christian evangelicals, according to early exit poll results, and about 3 in 10 are Catholic.
Catholic voters made up at least about one-third of voters in both New Hampshire and Florida - and in both of those states, they swung for Mr. Romney.
But only about one in seven voters in Michigan said that abortion mattered most to their vote today. Even among social conservatives, the economy was the No. 1 issue - nearly half of white evangelical voters said the economy mattered most to their decision, with nearly a quarter saying either abortion or the deficit mattered the most.
- 
6:46 P.M. | Caucus Click: A Diverse Electorate in Michigan
- 
6:32 P.M. | Romney Looks to Win Conservative Voters
When Mr. Romney won Nevada's caucus on the heels of another victory in Florida, his campaign argued that he had finally made inroads with voters who call themselves very conservative.
In fact, in Nevada, Mr. Romney finally won that category, capturing 46 percent of the "very conservative" vote, while Mr. Gingrich only took 25 percent and Mr. Santorum (who did not campaign much there) took 15 percent.
But was that a fluke? Many of those who said they were very conservative also were Mormons, a group much more inclined to vote for Mr. Romney, who is a Mormon.
And a few days later, Mr. Romney got walloped in Colorado, Missouri and Minnesota. Exit and entrance polling was not available, but Mr. Santorum's campaign claimed credit for scoring big among the most conservative voters in those states.
Now, watching how those voters cast their ballots in Michigan and Arizona will be very interesting.
In Michigan, Mr. Santorum should have an edge. He has been talking at length about social issues, speaking in the kind of language that helps to fire up the Tea Party and evangelical bases of the Republican Party.
Arizona might be a bit different. The candidates have spent less time there, and immigration is a bigger deal in the border state. How does that cut for very conservative voters? That's unclear. Mr. Romney has tacked sharply to the right on the issue of illegal immigration, but Mr. Santorum is no liberal on the issue either.
The results of the "very conservative" bloc are probably of greater importance for Mr. Romney, who still faces questions about his ability to excite that kind of voter. If he improves tonight, that will help his campaign going forward.

6:29 P.M. | Voter Portraits: Phoenix 
Name: Rand Vogel
Location: Phoenix
Age: 57
Political affiliation: Republican
Occupation: General contractor
Most important issue: Economy
Preferred candidate: Rick Santorum

6:22 P.M. | Exit Polls: Enthusiasm Gap in Arizona
An indicator of the lack of enthusiasm for the candidates on the ballot, half of Republican primary voters in Arizona said they strongly favored the candidate for whom they had just voted. Additionally, only about three in four said they would definitely vote for the Republican nominee in November. Among supporters of Mr. Paul, this figure was about one in three.
Only a bare majority of Arizona Republican primary voters said they had a favorable impression of Mr. McCain, the Republican nominee in the 2008 presidential election. Mr. McCain's tepid favorability suggests that his endorsement of Mr. Romney may not be influential. 
Three in five Arizona Republican primary voters said that working in business better prepared a candidate to serve as president than working in government. This was also the dominant view among supporters of every candidate except for Mr. Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, whose supporters were more favorable toward government experience.
Nearly half of Arizona voters said that last week's debate was an important factor in their vote.
- 
6:09 P.M. | Exit Polls: The Economy Wins Again
As was the case in every previous exit poll conducted in this nomination race, voters in the Arizona Republican primary overwhelmingly picked the economy as their No. 1 issue in deciding whom to support (about half of all responses). The second biggest issue cited by voters was the budget deficit (about one-third of responses). The economy was the top issue concern for supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, but supporters of Ron Paul felt that the budget deficit was more important.
Also repeating the pattern found in other exit polls this season, Arizona Republican primary voters said that the most important candidate quality was the ability to beat Mr. Obama (nearly two in five responses). While this was true among supporters of Mr. Romney, Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich, supporters of Mr. Paul were more likely to say that being a true conservative was the candidate quality they prized most (about one in three responses). 
Half of Republican primary goers in Arizona said that a candidate sharing their religious beliefs was somewhat or greatly important to their vote. 
Just as in 2008, about one in five voters said they believed abortion should be illegal in all cases.
While 40 percent of Republican primary voters in Florida said that most illegal immigrants working in the United States should be offered a chance to apply for citizenship, in Arizona this option received the support of only one in three - about equal to the number saying they should be deported. 
- 
6:01 P.M. | Santorum and Female Voters
Has Mr. Santorum angered women?
For the past week, Mr. Santorum has been taking positions that might turn off some women, especially independents from the suburbs. He focused on contraception for days and over the weekend called Mr. Obama a "snob" for advocating on behalf of college.
Those are subjects that may fire up Mr. Santorum's base, but they threaten to depress his vote among women, particularly in the parts of Michigan that are more moderate.
So the question will be whether women will decide they would rather support Mr. Romney, and whether that support will be enough to help overcome Mr. Romney's other weaknesses.
If that gender gap between the two candidates begins to widen as the night progresses, Mr. Santorum could find himself on the losing side tonight.
- 
5:58 P.M. | Exit Polls: College Graduates and Union Members
How well will Mr. Santorum's remarks about President Obama's being a "snob" about college education go over in Michigan, and who were his targets? 
Today's exit polls showed that about half of Michigan primary voters held a college degree, and about 3 in 10 had attended some college or held an associate's degree. In Florida, New Hampshire and Nevada, most college graduates supported Mr. Romney, while they were more divided in Iowa and South Carolina.
Michigan also has one of the highest union membership rates in the country. In today's primary, early exit poll results showed about one-quarter of voters said there was a union member in their household, and about one in seven said they were a union member themselves. In 2008, union households broke evenly for Mr. McCain and Mr. Romney.
- 
5:53 P.M. | Exit Polls: In Michigan, a More Moderate Electorate
With the first waves of exit polls in from voters in Michigan and Arizona, the state of Michigan has a slightly more moderate electorate than some previous Republican caucus and primary contests in 2012.
About 6 in 10 primary voters in Michigan consider themselves conservative, with about 3 in 10 saying they are very conservative and about the same number saying they are moderate, according to preliminary exit poll results.
One reason that Republican primary voters in Michigan may appear less conservative than other early nominating contests is that Michigan does not require voters to be registered Republicans, so anyone, including independents and Democrats, can temporarily call himself or herself a Republican and enter the voting booth.
And at least one candidate is taking advantage of that flexibility to try to improve his chances.
Mr. Romney has called Mr. Santorum's automated phone call lobbying Democrats to vote against Mr. Romney a "dirty trick." But Mr. Romney himself has admitted to voting in a Democratic primary as a registered independent, for Paul Tsongas, whom he thought would make the weakest Democratic presidential candidate in 1992.
So did Democrats really come out to vote in the Republican contest more than usual today? It's hard to say: Exit poll results showed that about 1 in 10 voters in Michigan today said they usually think of themselves as a Democrat. In 2008, 7 percent of Republican primary voters identified as Democrat, and in 2000, 17 percent did.
Of the other early nominating contests with exit polls, New Hampshire, which Mr. Romney won handily, had the most moderate electorate, with just 22 percent of voters saying they were very conservative, and a slim majority saying they were conservative.
In Nevada and Iowa, more than 8 in 10 voters said they were conservative, and nearly half of all primary voters said they were very conservative. Nearly 7 in 10 voters in South Carolina and Florida considered themselves conservative.
- 
5:26 P.M. | Video: Primary Day
- 
5:30 P.M. | Arizona Looks Like Less of a Nail-Biter
There are 29 delegates at stake in Arizona, and the Republicans gathered there last week for what was being billed as the last debate of the Republican contest. But in the end, the contest there is ending up as something of an afterthought, overshadowed by the fight going on in Michigan on Tuesday. The candidates have barely been in the state since the debate.
One reason? Polls suggest that this will be an easy win for Mr. Romney, the former Massachusetts governor. For what it's worth, he received the endorsement of Jan Brewer, the Republican governor of Arizona, last week, and has the backing of Senator John McCain. And the state has a sizable population of Mormons - Mr. Romney is a Mormon - who turned out at the campaign rallies he held during his last visit to the state last week.
Unlike Michigan, this is a closed primary, meaning that only registered Republicans are permitted to vote. Polls close at 9 p.m. Eastern time. In 2008, the primary was won by Mr. McCain in what was also something less than a nail-biter.
- 
5:28 P.M. | Could Early Voters Turn Michigan?
As the Michigan votes start rolling in tonight, keep an eye on the votes that were cast before today.
Early voting rewards campaigns that are highly organized, like Mr. Romney's. They can identify voters that might support a candidate, make sure they get an early ballot, and follow up to make sure voters fill out and returns their ballot.
The expectation is that Mr. Romney's campaign has done well in early voting in Michigan. That could give him an early lead as the voting gets under way. But that lead could evaporate if Mr. Santorum's election-day voters turn out in much larger numbers.
Early voting has already made a difference in the 2012 campaign. Mr. Romney's campaign methodically pushed his supporters in Florida to vote early, helping him defeat Newt Gingrich during the primary there at the end of last month.
Will it make the same difference in Michigan? We should know soon enough.
- 
5:13 P.M. | Setting the Stage in Michigan and Arizona
The intensity of the rhetorical battle between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum before the primaries in Michigan and Arizona would suggest that a denouement might finally be at hand.
But it's possible that little will be settled Tuesday night.
In part, that's because the race in Michigan appears to be very close; a matter of just a few thousand votes could separate the victor from his nearest competitor. Winning by a hair will hardly confer unstoppable momentum.
There's also the delegate count. Almost all of Michigan's delegates are awarded at the district level: two delegates for the winner of each Congressional district. The rules raise the real possibility that the winner of the popular vote could be on the losing end of the delegate tally.
And finally, there's Arizona. A decisive win there for Mr. Romney - who is far ahead in the state polls, even as he struggles in Michigan - would muddle the political picture from the two contests even further.

HEADLINE: Live Blogging Michigan and Arizona Primaries

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Times is providing live updates and analysis from the Republican primaries in Michigan and Arizona. 

 BODY:
The race for the Republican presidential nomination is not likely to be settled on Tuesday, though much is at stake for Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as voters in Michigan and Arizona head to the polls. 
The Times is covering Tuesday's contests and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.
Live Dashboard Download the Election 2012 App: iPhone | AndroidTwitter: @thecaucus | The Times Political Unit | @fivethirtyeightResults: Michigan | Arizona
11:53 P.M. | That's a Wrap
Mitt Romney has been declared the winner in Michigan and Arizona, the candidates have given their speeches and are now on their way home, and we are, too. Check out NYTimes.com and The Caucus for continuing coverage. Thanks for following along.
And don't forget to download the new Election 2012 app, now available on Android, which smartly combines our coverage with the best from political news sites, Twitter and blogs from around the Web.

11:27 P.M. | Anti-Bailout Position Does Not Hurt Romney
Given Mr. Romney's 2008 Op-Ed piece opposing government aid to Detroit automakers, many expected this issue to resonate in the state's Republican primary. Even Mr. Santorum's campaign made a last-minute push to get disgruntled union workers to vote against Mr. Romney for this reason. While primary voters were almost evenly divided on the issue, those who supported the bailout were no more likely to back Mr. Santorum over Mr. Romney.
On the other hand, union membership did make a significant difference in voters' preferences. One in eight voters said they personally belonged to a union and one in four said someone in their household did. Mr. Santorum handily won both of these groups, but lost to Mr. Romney among nonunion households.
- 
10:55 P.M. | Breaking Down Romney's Support
Mr. Romney's big victory in Arizona and his strong showing in Michigan were both largely fueled by the same coalition of voters that have consistently expressed their support for Mr. Romney in exit polls throughout the primary season. In particular, Mr. Romney once again did best among older voters, better educated voters and higher income voters.
In terms of issues, Mr. Romney won in both states by large margins among voters who felt that the economy was the most important issue and among those who felt the budget deficit was the most important issue.
Voters who were looking primarily for a candidate who could beat Mr. Obama also gravitated to Mr. Romney, as did those who said experience was the most important candidate quality.
Mr. Romney, who has had to answer questions about his positions on abortion, also did much better than his opponents among voters who would approve of abortion being legal in most or all cases.
In recent weeks, Mr. Romney has been less of a favorite than he had been before the voting started in January, but he continues to do best among voters who say they made up their minds before January.
Arizona Mormons Provided an Edge

Mr. Romney polled slightly better overall in Arizona than in Michigan, but the exit polls reveal that an important source of his advantage in Arizona may have been the state's Mormon population.
Among almost every group, Mr. Romney actually polled about the same in Arizona as he did in Michigan. However, his performance was surprisingly strong in a few areas. One clear advantage was among the state's Mormon population. Mormons made up nearly one out of every seven voters in Arizona's primary. Mr. Romney carried 9 in 10 of these Mormon votes.
But this advantage among Mormons also appeared to produce some other unusual voting patterns. For example, while Mr. Paul had been consistently winning younger voters, in Arizona, Mr. Romney won twice as many votes among those 18 to 29. This reason becomes more clear when one considers that Mormon voters are considerably younger than the typical Arizona voter. While 1 in 10 Arizona voters overall were between 18 to 29, among Mormons nearly 4 in 10 fell into this age category.
Similarly, while Mr. Romney had generally been losing among voters in other states who said abortion should be illegal in all cases, he drew almost as much support in Arizona as Mr. Santorum (about two in five of these voters). However, if Mormon voters are excluded, Mr. Romney won only half as many anti-abortion votes as Mr. Santorum.
- 
10:43 P.M. | Romney Declares Victory, With a Sense of Relief
NOVI, Mich. - There was a palpable sense of relief on the faces of Mr. Romney's aides as Michigan was called for their candidate - by four or five points - and they emerged from their backstage holding area. Senior advisers high-fived one another and hugged, and made little effort to hide the profound relief they felt over averting an embarrassing defeat. At least one Michigan staff member had tears in her eyes.
When Mr. Romney took the stage, at first accompanied by his wife, Ann, and his oldest son, Tagg, Mrs. Romney made a point of giving shout-outs to a long list of Michigan surrogates - including Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, Donald Trump and Kid Rock, who played a mini-show (a lone number: the Romney campaign's theme song, "Born Free") Monday night.
And Mr. Romney, before beginning his victory night speech that attacked Mr. Obama, also acknowledged what a squeaker the race had become.
"We didn't win by a lot, but we won by enough, and that's all that counts," Mr. Romney said, thanking the volunteers who had knocked on doors and made phone calls for his campaign.
Mr. Romney declared his win in Michigan to be a "great victory" and used his speech to assail Mr. Obama's leadership as he vowed to oust him from the White House.
Mr. Romney did not mention Mr. Santorum or his other rivals in the speech, preferring instead to keep his attention trained on the general election.
"Our campaign, as you know, is about restoring the promise of America," Mr. Romney said during remarks in Michigan. "I'm going to deliver on more jobs, less debt, smaller government."
For Mr. Romney, the victory in Michigan - and another in Arizona - was a much-needed push in his efforts to become the Republican Party's nominee.
But he used the platform of a nationally televised speech to skip over the remaining months of the primary to discuss what could be a battle with Mr. Obama in the fall.
"These days when he's not spending our money or infringing on our rights, he's running for re-election," Mr. Romney said of the president. "He thinks he deserves a second term. He says we can't wait, to which I say, oh yes, we can."
- 
10:39 P.M. | Santorum Addresses Supporters and Pivots to Ohio
Mr. Santorum declared himself thankful for placing second in Michigan's primary on Tuesday, saying that he "came into the backyard of one of my opponents" and did well where no one had expected him to.
Mr. Santorum talked for about 20 minutes without directly acknowledging that he had failed to win the Michigan primary and barely mentioned the name of Mr. Romney, his chief rival.
Instead, he quickly sought to return to the message of small government and help for manufacturing that had dominated his campaign before he began talking about social issues in the past week.
"It's getting harder for people to make ends meet because we have a government that is crushing us every single day," Mr. Santorum said.
He pledged an energy policy that expands oil drilling and criticized Mr. Obama as a leader who always says "no" to the efforts of Americans to produce energy.
"We need a president who says 'yes' to the American people on energy production," Mr. Santorum said.
With an eye on the Ohio primary coming up in a week, Mr. Santorum renewed his pledge to take the corporate tax on manufacturing to zero - an issue that could play well in the Rust Belt state.
He also vowed to repeal Mr. Obama's health care plan. It was then that he mentioned Mr. Romney by name, saying that Republicans needed a candidate who would provide a contrast with the president.
"Not Romneycare or Obamacare," he said, but "you care, because that's what we believe in in America."

10:34 P.M. | Santorum Is Strong With Conservatives in Michigan
Leading up to today's primaries, Mr. Santorum campaigned heavily in Michigan, but spent little time or money in Arizona, and that bet showed at the polls.
According to exit poll results, Mr. Santorum found strength among a number of important groups in Michigan to rival Mr. Romney in his home state: union households, strong supporters of the Tea Party, white evangelical Christians and those who consider themselves very conservative.
He also held a strong advantage over Mr. Romney among Michigan voters who said it mattered somewhat or a great deal that a candidate share their religious beliefs, and those who said being a true conservative or having strong moral character mattered most in their vote.
While Mr. Santorum's recent lobbying effort to sway social conservatives to his side may have worked with evangelical Christians, it did not lure Catholic voters - their vote was divided between him and Mr. Romney. Nearly half of Catholic female voters in Michigan went for Mr. Romney, compared with less than a third for Mr. Santorum.
Voters in Michigan had concerns about Mr. Santorum's electability, hurting his opportunity of snatching the state away from Mr. Romney. Only about a quarter of Michigan primary voters said Mr. Santorum was the candidate most likely to defeat Mr. Obama in November, and electability ranked among the most important factors for voters.
The economy was the overarching issue for Michigan voters, and nearly half of those who said the economy was their main concern were supporting Mr. Romney.
Mr. Santorum had a difficult time finding any groups to support him in large enough numbers to make a difference in his bid in Arizona, where he had little to no campaign presence and where his debate performance last week was considered lackluster.
In Arizona, Mr. Romney swept nearly all voting blocs. Mr. Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator, only led Mr. Romney - and not by much - among strong Tea Party supporters, white evangelical Christians, and late-deciding voters, and was tied or nearly tied with Mr. Romney among the lowest income and the most conservative voters.
